video_title: The market's biggest concern is tariffs, the endgame is unknown, says Oppenheimer's John Stoltzfus

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Oppenheimer Asset Management's John Stoltzfus is here. John, you know, we often see this reaction to a tariff headline. If it's 15 to 20 percent on the EU, we'll wait for more detail on that. Do you want to kind of put that into context for us in terms of how important you think that headline is?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, Kelly, we've been saying for quite a while now that we think that the market's biggest concern is the tariffs, because the end point on the tariffs is still unknown. Negotiations either in progress or sort of out there on the distant horizon in case of some others. And the market looks at it as to what will be the effect within sectors, within market capitalizations, and even within style, growth versus value.  And that's what the worry is, because, on the other hand, we have seen, in terms of revenue and earnings growth, that's going fine. The Fed has done a good job in slowing the pace of inflation. And we have got the consumer remarkably resilient relative to all the — we had, what, 11 hikes, and then three cuts, and over nine pauses at this point.  So where we are, no recession. We're doing good on that hand. It's the tariffs that are the concerning point.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right. So when you say the concerning point, a lot of people, you know, try to extrapolate out to the end outcome. The market's been shrugging off the headlines in large part lately. I mean, the EU is a biggie, though.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I think most certainly, because it's a major trade partner. And what we've got to figure here is that until we get some kind of agreement that looks livable, this volatility remains an issue. And I think that the problem is that  You know, Europe is now is working, considering other partners, in terms of trade, to offset what it might lose with the U.S. But I think that, ultimately, the longer-term relationship that exists between the region and our country will see something that will arrive that will be livable for both the consumer, for both the importer  or the exporter, rather, and for the importer. It can be worked out, but at a lower rate than what we're hearing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know, this touches on a little chat we had with Tim Seymour yesterday, John, where he said, look, this U.S. exceptionalism narrative got way overblown. You go back to January, and it was all about how big we were in terms of global market cap, how well the market had done, where were the European innovators, so on and so forth. Of course, now international markets have kind of trounced us. But you say you believe U.S. exceptionalism remains very much intact.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Oh, absolutely. We really feel that it does remain intact. And it has to do with innovation and technology. The run that we see when we look around the world and we've been global investors for just about just about 40 years at this point.  It is that it was valuation, which was extremely low in comparison to the U.S., which has inevitably helped the international markets, and then with expectations that there would be some kind of agreement in terms of all these tariffs.  Really, it's not the end of globalization. The rest of the world feeds into this. But we believe that the U.S., particularly as perhaps as Bill Gross used to say, the cleanest dirty shirt and a hamper of dirty shirts, if all countries are a hamper of dirty shirts, exceptionalism remains a brand of the U.S. when you consider the effects of technology.  and around the world in society business and consumers deeply have technology deeply embedded in their lives.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Kelly anchors the discussion, focussing on the market's reaction to EU tariff headlines. She probes the significance of the EU as a trade partner and the potential extrapolations of tariff outcomes. Kelly also touches upon the recent shift in performance between U.S. and international markets.
summary.SPEAKER_01: John Stoltzfus emphasises that tariffs are the primary market concern due to their uncertainty. He highlights the resilience of the U.S. economy but notes that tariff volatility will persist until a livable agreement is reached with the EU. Stoltzfus asserts that U.S. exceptionalism remains intact, driven by innovation and technology, despite the recent outperformance of international markets.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the impact of EU tariffs on the market, the role of tariffs in market volatility, and the persistence of U.S. exceptionalism.

video_title: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller Talks Labor Market, Fed Chair | Bloomberg Talks

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Bloomberg Audio Studios.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Podcasts, radio, news.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Making the case for a rate cut. Fed Governor Chris Waller telling an audience here in New York, looking across the soft and hard data, I get a picture of a labor market on the edge. Joining us now here in New York City, the Federal Reserve Governor, Chris Waller. Governor Waller, good morning. Oh, good morning, Jonathan, Lisa, Anne Marie. Nice to be here. It's good to see you, sir. Let's talk about why we're losing the luxury of waiting. Have we lost that already?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No, I think we haven't. Like I said last night, the headline numbers for the labor market, what we're seeing, are OK. But it's like when you get underneath and start looking at the data, the private sector is not doing as well as everybody thinks it is. Most of the, half of the employment growth we saw last month was in the public sector. And that means the private sector is not doing particularly well. So I was just joking that, you know,  You know, if you're walking on a lake and the ice is frozen and it sounds safe, but when you start hearing cracks, and that's what I feel like, it's too late once you go through the ice. So you've got to start prepping in advance before you have that happen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How do you square that with what we've heard from corporate America so far? What corporate America has told Lisa sitting down with Scott Kirby of United Airlines talking about a rebound in the second half. What we've heard from the big banks so far this week. How do you square what you're seeing in the data with what we're hearing from CEOs?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, I mean when I talk to CEOs I get the same thing. We're in just hold pattern in terms of certainly the labor market. They're not hiring, they're not firing, they're just watching. And that's kind of what you see in this underlying private sector data. There's not much happening. So it wouldn't take much to sort of tip it. Now, could I be wrong? Absolutely.  I mean, last year we got a couple of weak labor market reports that led us to cut in September, and then everything kind of reversed and went back up. So I'm not saying that couldn't happen again, but it's just we've constantly seen little bits of data continually coming down. The Beige Book yesterday came out. Some other stuff, when you get out of the jolts, quits rates, hiring rates, these things are not indicating a super healthy private sector labor market.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: As you know, you're facing potentially, and I stress potentially, negative supply shocks on both sides of the mandate. I want to sit on the labor market just for one further note. Immigration. How are you thinking about that when you look at the labor market at the moment? When we have people coming on the program, on Bloomberg Surveillance, on Bloomberg TV, every single morning, 6 till 9, coming on here and saying, look at the data. Unemployment could stay at these levels even with job gains of 50,000 to 100,000 because of tighter immigration. How does that factor into your thinking as you look at the US labor market?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, yeah, the labor market doesn't necessarily have to be affected by it because if workers flow in and they get jobs at roughly the same rate as the existing workers, the unemployment rate doesn't change even though the labor force is higher. And when they go back out, the same thing happens. If they leave the employment and leave the labor force, you don't see a big change in the inflation rate. Now, it can potentially affect the break-even rate that you would need to have the market going well.  And that's what we're still trying to get a sense of. Because you basically brought five years of immigration forward. And of that eight or nine million, most of them haven't disappeared. So they're still here somewhere. Whether they're going to work, they're not going to work, but they're still here. Where I think the immigration stuff, if immigration was a big factor, you'd be seeing shortages. And you might see some in some industries. But like I pointed out, if you look at the new college graduate,  unemployment rate, it's 7%. It's much higher than it has. These are not jobs that are being opened up because immigrants are not coming in. This should be just the opposite. If immigrants are leaving and these jobs are open, then the unemployment rate should go the other way. So that unemployment rate to me is telling me immigration is not the source of the problem. Firms are just holding off on hiring decisions.  Even if their earnings are doing well, that's just what I'm saying they're doing on the labor side.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I wanted to say there's a mutual friend of ours that feels like he's missing out this morning, so I wanted to catch up with you as well. He's out in Victor, Idaho, isn't he? He's having a good time, isn't he? Mike McKee joins us now. Good morning, Mike.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Good morning, John, and good morning, Governor Waller. I would say I'm sorry I'm not there with you, but I bet you're sorry you're not here with me. You got it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I've been there before. It's a nice place.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You've made the case now a couple of times for a July rate cut, but how committed are you? Are you willing to dissent at this meeting if the majority votes the other way?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I never want to commit to an action before the meeting. Otherwise, if everybody committed before, you don't even need to have the meeting to have a discussion. So the goal is to always go to the meeting, sit down, listen to all sides. People will try to convince me of their view. I'll try to convince them of my views. And in the end of the day, you make the decision on what you think is the right outcome and the right data, how the data is coming in. And right now, I laid out my case last. I don't think I could be any more clear, I hope.  as to what my position is and why I think we need to do this. It's just how I read the data and how I think about going forward, how you respond to anything that involves tariffs.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: There's a lot of politics in this decision coming up, more than usual. And I'm wondering, Governor Bowman has also suggested she would prefer a rate cut in July. If two of you vote for a rate cut, if two of you were to dissent, would you worry about the market reaction to that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You know, one of the things that has always bothered me since I took this job is the criticism that we are nothing but groupthink. All the meetings are the same. Nobody dissents. Nobody does anything. And I think this is healthy. I think this is a turning point in the way we want to think about policy. Some people don't want to cut. Some do want to cut. But coming out and making the case either side  That's good, healthy debate. Otherwise, if we're always going to do the same, the joke is, why don't you just have one person set policy and send the other 18 FOMC members home? So this is healthy. I think this is what you want to see in a democracy. You want to see policymakers have serious, open discussion about where policy should go. It doesn't mean anything about politics or anything else. It's make the economic argument.  and then see if you can convince others to go along with you. And that's all I'm trying to do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We totally agree with you, for the record. We were sick of the group think and it's good to have dissent. Mike essentially is asking if you will dissent at the end of this month. Is there value in dissenting on the FOMC?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I mean, it's often the case that you dissent if you make it very clear you think at this moment in time this is an important thing to do. If you were to go in and do kind of a jihadist, I'm going to dissent at every single meeting no matter what happens, then you don't even have to show up. Everybody knows what you're going to do.  So it is important to make sure that if you dissent, you do it carefully, and you have the right reasons, and it's not going to turn into a serial dissenting potential case. I mean, that's how I take my job, seriously and responsibly. So I only would think about doing this. I dissented on the balance sheet slowdown earlier this year because I felt like that was not needed. And that's kind of the situation we're in now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Chris, if you do cut, the markets will go one way. If you don't, they'll go another, perhaps. How critical is it to get to a rate cut fairly quickly? You've mentioned the danger to the labor market, but if you do wait until September, is that going to be too late?  Well, that's kind of the debate.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: What does it mean to wait six weeks? Is it that critical? And the answer is probably not. It could be. But it's also the reverse. Why wait till September if it's just six weeks? That's exactly the thing. It doesn't kind of matter. Just start thinking about, do I want to wait and risk something happening? This is what we saw last summer, by the way. We left July. We left rates. And then, boom, we got a very weak  Bad labor market reports. Unemployment rate jumped two-tenths. Payrolls went way down from where they were. And people were screaming at us last August, you guys should have cut in July. So one month, Ken, it always is one month. Just remember that. It's just one month.  But we live in a world in which we have to respond to real-time data to kind of sense of where the economy is going. And I've always said, if you worry about long and variable lags, which everybody always talks about, the whole point of that is to get ahead of it, not wait for it to happen, and then take a policy action that takes quarters or months down the road to actually have any impact.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: The new worry is tariffs. We've just had a six-minute conversation with you about monetary policy. You've built a case for lower interest rates, and no one's talked about trade or inflation.  Two assumptions in your speech yesterday, and I think they're important assumptions. A large share of tariff increases won't be passed through to consumers. Any increase would fade over the next year or so. What data underpins that conclusion?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, one, it's just, first, it's just economic theory. So you put on a tariff. As long as it's a one-time tariff and that's it,  That's a one-time price effect. I mean, this is economic theory. You could not get in any serious economic model persistent inflation from that. You would have to cook up some other amplification mechanisms, and that's what people talk about. Wages will start going up and everything will get out of control. You're not seeing that at all. This is just not. Those kind of amplification mechanisms are wage-price spirals aren't happening.  Tariffs are a tax. And in public finance, you learn that you may levy a tax on a firm, but who bears the incidence or the burden of that tax? It can be a group of people or one person, not necessarily the firm. So this is what I've heard from a lot of firms. If there's a 10% tax, they'll force their suppliers to eat some of that cost. Workers may eat some of that cost in terms of less hiring and things like that. The firm will take it out of their profit margins.  And then lastly, some of it will get passed on. And as I mentioned last night, I've heard this for months now. The rule is 10% is roughly, rule of thumb is a third, a third, a third. Suppliers will eat a third. Firms will eat a third. Consumers are going to eat a third of that tariff. So if you eat a third of it, and it's 10%, like I've been arguing, this is like 3 tenths of a, 3 tenths on the inflation rate for a few months. And that's it.  And it'll persist if you do 12-month over 12-month. That base effect will not go away for a while, and then it'll just drop off a cliff. So that's why I've been arguing you want to look at like 3-month and 6-months to see if these tariff effects pop up and then go away. And so that's more critical than looking at 12-month.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yes, but the way the president is putting these tariffs on might not match up with theory, Chris. The Smoot-Hawley tax was passed and came into effect on a certain date. The president has not yet put on most of these tariffs. They're in theory still coming.  And we still haven't seen the Section 232 tariffs for the most part, the national defense tariffs that he wants to put on semiconductors and pharmaceuticals, et cetera. So if the process is stretched out, consumers could be hit by a series, an ongoing series of tariff increases. And given what they've just been through, isn't there a danger that inflation psychology starts to seep in?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, that's exactly the point. All my example has been is if you put the 10% uniform tariff on and keep it roughly in that range,  then what I've described is what will happen. If there's constantly a sequence of higher and higher and higher tariffs, then you are going to get this rolling potential impact on prices. That's true. If it's still just a question of delaying it, that doesn't change my argument. Whether you see the spike in July or it happens in June or August or September, when it happens is irrelevant for the economics. That's a non-starter of an argument.  Firms could also just spread it out in smaller increments over several months. The total effect still ends up being the same. They just get there in a later fashion. And it will be smaller amounts. So the bigger thing is if we just continue to get another wave of tariffs, another wave of tariffs, another wave of tariffs, that's when things become more problematic thinking about what's going to happen with inflation.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You don't think the Federal Reserve should wait. I just want to talk about the experience of last year. I think Lisa's done a fantastic job of covering this over the last six, seven, eight months. The move we saw last year, 100 basis point reduction in interest rates on Fed funds. And then we saw a corresponding move of 100 basis points higher at the long end of the yield curve. Yields down did not happen. It was yields up and mortgage costs up as well. How do you think one informed the other? And how might that shape your approach to cutting interest rates this time around?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think last September there was a lot of – remember, the long-term rates were going down through August and early September. This was not any contradiction of what we were doing. It's just after the September meeting, the data just came back in the opposite way. Growth was up, productivity was up, employment suddenly took back off. And then you have  real growth expectations being much higher. We were seeing productivity growth and GDP growth of close to 3%. So in that case, long rates go up anyway. summary.Joel Wertheimer: Joel Wertheimer, a civil rights lawyer, provides insights into how AI is currently being used in the legal field, particularly in litigation. video_title: Deputy Treasury Secretary: Legislative clarity will give people confidence to utilize crypto

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Coin hitting a record high this week as a number of regulatory bills move through the House. One bill, the Genius Act, would regulate stable coins. It's expected to be signed by the president today. Joining us now is Deputy Treasury Secretary Michael Falkender. It's great to have you on. Beyond adding legitimacy to crypto and safety to crypto, what do you think this bill allows for when it comes to the system?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Great to be with you. It's a great day for the American people because we are going to provide regulatory and legislative clarity to the use of stablecoins for modernizing the payment system. As we identify new ways to use technology, we can more quickly, more cheaply and more securely facilitate payment around the world. And so what this is going to do is it's going to even further  cement the dollar as the world's reserve currency because by making it easier for people trading internationally, for imports and exports, for trade even domestically to take place through electronic means, through blockchain technology, by providing this legislative clarity for those participating in this space, they know the rules of the road, they know how to operate, and it'll bring faith to the American people on how to negotiate, how to make payments, how to utilize these new systems.  Let me also make one other point about this. This innovation has been going on. And if we do not provide this kind of clarity, then what's going to happen is the innovation is going to take place abroad. And the last thing that the American people want to see, or the people who have values of the West, the last thing they want to see is the Chinese taking the lead on international standard setting. And so by providing clear rules of the road, that then facilitates us working with partners around the world  to have the U.S. system of stablecoins be the dominant means by which we engage in electronic commerce.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It's clear who the winners are. I mean, we just showed a few of them, Coinbase, Robinhood, Circle, everyone that, the crypto companies. Who are the losers? Does this hurt ultimately the credit card issuers if it makes cross-border transactions with crypto more legit?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I think what it does is it changes the way it provides new competition in the foreign remittance space. So rather than being reliant on sending foreign wires, using correspondent banking relationships that can sometimes take 24, 48, 72 hours to move money internationally,  You can in minutes, if not faster, securely, cheaply send money around the world and thereby facilitate even faster trade than what takes place when we're using these more, you know, let's call it historic ways of  of making payments internationally. So, you know, I have said before, if I were still operating a very traditional foreign remittance type business, then this would be, this is quite an emerging challenge to that traditional structure.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Like a MoneyGram, those kind of companies.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I would say, I wonder what you think actors around the world who are opposed to dollar dominance, how they will respond to this news.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, like I said, I think that this further cements the position of the dollar as the world's reserve currency, because as this innovation takes place, as we make it easier for trade now to be processed in dollar-based currency, you know, invoiced and paid for,  in dollars than any argument that was being made about why you might instead invoice in renminbi or in euros. I think that as we ensure that we have the most technologically advanced with a legal structure around it, you're going to see even more confidence in using dollar-based invoicing and dollar-based trade, which again increases the demand for dollar-based reserves and further cements the dollar as the world's reserve currency. So yeah,  If there are other countries around the world that want to see their currency be in a more prominent position, this legislation is critical for us to push back on that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right. And Besson's been pretty clear about that in his testimony recently. I wonder, there's going to have to be sort of a large public education effort, isn't there, as we get these stable coins issued? We're awash in headlines from companies and banks that are considering it right now. How do you make that simple to understand for regular Americans?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Right. And I think I'll just remind people that this is just the latest technological innovation in financial services. I remind people all the time. You know we used to go into banks. Now we use automated teller machines. We used to make deposits in person and now we can make them through our phones. We do a lot of things through the you know that this is just the latest way of.  using technology to make it faster, cheaper, and more secure. And so the private sector providers of this, yes, are going to have to educate their customers. And just as we have shifted to other more modern forms of technology in financial services, it's going to be incumbent on the providers to explain to users and build out their confidence in how these new platforms are going to work.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I just wanted to share some of the recent economic data that we had. We got improvement in University of Michigan consumer sentiment and also lower expectations of both short- and long-term inflation, which continues to pick a better picture of the economy. I'm wondering how you are thinking about second-half growth now that we are seeing confidence come back.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, and let me add one more data point in there, which is the retail sales number yesterday blew out expectations because this economy is growing a lot stronger than a lot of the pessimists in the media have wanted to give it credit for. But we knew that this was going to happen because we're returning to the magic sauce that President Trump unleashed in his first term. Deregulation, permanency in the tax cuts, resolving some of these international trading issues, builds confidence,  brings back manufacturing and private sector jobs to the United States. That's what facilitates productivity improvements, creates growth opportunities. And we are seeing the American people realize that this economic plan is, just as it did in the 2017 to 2019 timeframe, going to bring back affordable growth for the American people. And so you see them outspending without price increases, because by increasing on the supply side, by generating the incentives for more domestic production,  we can have that higher level of sales without inflation because we're going to produce more here in the United States.

lines.text: And I know the president wants to see lower rates because of the sort of no inflation. Even though there are upside risks, you have to admit, to inflation. lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, that really doesn't fall into the Treasury lane. Instead, what we want to do is make sure that the president casts a wide net as he thinks about who his next Fed chair is going to be. But just like he's done with the rest of his cabinet, I am I am very confident that the president is going to select an outstanding next Fed chair. And I think we're more focused on the future and making sure that we get somebody in there who is going to facilitate growth and make sure that we have the right interest rate environment  to take advantage of all of these pro-growth activities that the president is unleashing with his economic plan.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And lower interest rates. I mean, that feels like it has to be a criteria, right, that they want lower rates right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Again, to the extent that we unleash supply, then there is no reason for us to anticipate that inflation would come with it, in which case one should question why we continue to have one of the highest interest rate environments in the world when we are not seeing inflation materialize in the data.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Alright, well we appreciate you joining us on the big day for crypto.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Great to be with you. Absolutely, great day for the American people.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It's good to see you Mr. Deputy Secretary Michael Falkender.

So we're definitely seeing that a lot of that front loading took place.  There is sort of a very temporary surge right now of folks trying to get air freight in, especially from these Southeast Asian countries where you have an August 1st deadline for the higher tariffs. And they're saying, hey, let's get these goods in as fast as we can. So we've seen a lot of containers that were going to go ocean freight switch to air just to be able to beat that deadline and pay a lower duty rate.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: But bottom line, you don't expect necessarily a lot of shortages going into holiday?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: No, not really. I mean, I think people really saw these terrorists. We knew since last November, when Trump got elected, that there would be higher duties. And so people that first half of the year did a lot of front-loading. And then he kept the duty rates low all the way until right now in August.  So people managed to move goods in knowing that these higher duty rates would be coming. So we'll see. I think if you see shortage, it'll be because these tariff rates go way up and it starts to cause businesses a lot of pain. But that'll take many months from this August 1st period to see how it shakes out into the business world.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So what do you see overall, Ryan, for demand? Like which routes are more heavy demand and which ones are lower?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, the China to U.S. trade lane is down about 16 percent year over year. That's that's actually seems kind of good from our perspective, because where we were when the duty rate was one hundred and forty five percent for those five weeks after the April 2nd announcement, you saw at that moment bookings, ocean freight volumes fell by 60 percent.  So right now we're only down 60% and it's like, okay, it's pretty stable really in the scheme of things. China reports that their overall exports are up 5%, but to the US is down 16%. So that's quite a trend. And then what's really happened at least for the last 90 days was a huge surge out of Southeast Asia.  Thailand, Vietnam being two of the big winners there. But of course, they've been hit with higher duty rates announced for August 1st. We're still waiting for the Code of Federal Regulations to actually make that official. As of right now, we just have some statements from the president, which that's not how customs duties work. So we're all waiting to see when the actual rules come out and what they look like.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: But that's Southeast Asia to the United States. What about to Europe and to other places outside the United States? What does that look like?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I mean, you see, things are relatively normal at this point. The consumer demand, I mean, no one's pointing to Europe as this huge, booming consumer demand, but they haven't had tariff, big tariff changes or anything, so it's pretty stable in terms of the scheme of things.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: In the meantime, Ryan, a few weeks ago, we were paying a lot of attention to the Middle East and the Red Sea and the Straits of Hormuz. We have had the Houthis try to get active in sinking some vessels. But how would you characterize the risk over there right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, there was some hope with the ceasefire that we saw between Iran and Israel and Trump's efforts to get to bring some sort of stability to the region that maybe that would lead to the reopening of the Red Sea and the Suez Canal. Container ships have not been transiting the Suez Canal since December of 2023, and that is now out the window. The Houthis sank  a cargo ship in the Red Sea recently. And so now, you know, there's no one who's thinking, OK, we can now return to the Red Sea, at least for the foreseeable future. That's a really big deal for ocean freight. Obviously, the containers going through there, I think it's around 30 percent of world's container traffic goes through the used to go through the Red Sea on an annual basis. So the rates have been artificially high because of that. And it looks like they're going to stay higher until that changes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, arguably a bigger issue for Europe than for the United States. But it does affect everybody. Ryan, appreciate it. Really good survey data. I imagine you are really busy. Come back soon.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Ryan Peterson, CEO of Flexport, reports that 77% of their customers have enough inventory due to front-loading. He notes a temporary surge in air freight to beat the August 1st tariff deadline. Peterson explains that the China to U.S. trade lane is down 16% YoY, while Southeast Asia has seen a surge, but will also face higher duties. He emphasises the stability in Europe and the ongoing impact of the closed Suez Canal on global trade rates.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host introduces the topic and asks about inventory trajectory, potential shortages, and demand patterns. They also inquire about the risks in the Middle East affecting ocean freight.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The second host asks follow-up questions about specific trade routes, such as Southeast Asia to Europe and the broader impact of the Middle East tensions on global trade, particularly focusing on the effects on Europe.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the current state of ocean freight, inventory levels, and trade patterns ahead of the August 1st tariff deadline. It highlights the impact of front-loading, tariff changes, and regional tensions on global trade.

video_title: US Stocks Are Expensive. You Should Still Buy Them | Merryn Talks Money

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Bloomberg Audio Studios. Podcasts, radio, news.  Welcome to Merrin Talks Money, the podcast in which people who know the markets explain the markets. I'm Merrin Sums up web. This week, I'm joined by Natalia Lipikina, head of EMEA's equity strategy and an executive director at J.V. Morgan Private Bank. We're going to talk about her current outlook on the equity markets as a whole, her take on the great rotation to the extent there is one, and what she sees happening to the dollar over the next few months.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Plus, of course, a little more. Natalia, welcome to Merrin Talks Money. Thank you so much for having me.  Good of you to join us today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Now, I think if we're going to talk about equity markets at all, we've got to start on the U.S., the biggest and the boldest of all of them. What is your outlook there? And we keep talking on this podcast about the great rotation and about how money is just just definitely going to move out of America into other markets. Valuations in the U.S. will come down. Valuations elsewhere will go up. But it never seems to quite happen in the volume that we expect.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We are actually quite still constructive on the U.S. market. We like other markets like Europe, but we don't want to abandon the United States of America. And I think it's fascinating to see how quick the recovery has actually been since April lows. S&P was down close to 20% at some point this year, and we're now making all-time highs again.  And I think the reason is because the markets and participants got more comfortable with AI story again. At the beginning of the year, there were loads of questions around AI, the deep seek, and all the money that has been invested into AI, if that leads to any side of returns. Now, when you look into the earning season that just happened in the first quarter, we actually got the confirmation that AI trade is still ongoing.  Companies continue to spend money despite the tariff uncertainty. And we're just one or two weeks before the earnings season again. And we just think that the tech companies and AI companies will continue to do well. And remember, U.S. market is predominantly tech driven. So the outlook on tech is very important.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: OK, so when you look at valuations, maybe I'm too valuation orientated, but when I look at the US, for example, we still have pretty much the most expensive valuations ever seen, apart from 2000, etc.  And you look at any valuation method, it doesn't matter what you look at, it's still close to historic highs. And every time you've seen valuations at this kind of level, you see returns in the following decade pretty weak. So if that doesn't happen this time, it'll be a bit of a historical anomaly, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I would say that we are quite comfortable with where the valuation can actually stay. We're in the camp that valuation can be between 20-21 times next 12 months price to earnings. And the reason for that is when you look into where tech is right now, in terms of the weighting, in terms of the net income, it's so much better and so much more important than it has been in the last 10-15 years.  The S&P market is predominantly driven by tech. And if you look underneath the sector, you basically have margins that are improving and you have the AI story. Now, I want to emphasize on AI story because AI doesn't just equal tech. The penetration of AI doubled over the last year or so. And what AI actually is, it means that some companies can become more efficient.  by efficient, meaning that their margin can actually be higher longer term. All of that actually deserves a higher valuation. So if you look into the CapEx intensity, those tech businesses are just less CapEx intense. Their margins continue to grow, they continue to invest into AI, and this is the reason why we're just comfortable with the multiple of where it is right now.  Again, fascinating to see. Valuation is back to 22 times as we speak, despite the worries around tariffs, despite the worries about where earnings will be this year. And I think the fundamental reason for that is tech.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Another one of the conversations that we have over and over and over is at what point do profit margins in the U.S. revert to some kind of mean? Because again, you have historically high profit margins, and you might say, well, because of AI, because of this, because of that. But nonetheless, historically, these things do tend to revert to a bit of a mean. And when you see things at this level, what happens is maybe there's a different type of competition, or maybe there's a new series of regulations, et cetera, et cetera. Something usually comes in  to reduce margins when they hit this kind of peak, but you don't think that's going to happen this time. You see them continuing to expand.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, I think it depends how quickly businesses adopt AI. Right now you have less than 10% of companies adopting AI. I think it's quite a low number compared to what benefits AI can actually bring to the business.  Now, if companies do embrace the AI adoption, that should lead to better margins overall. Now, if you're talking about more cyclical downturn, of course it can happen. Cyclical downturn can happen at any point in time, right? It may happen with tariffs, for example. We still don't know what tariffs will bring this year, right? We're still in the wait-to-see mode. For example, for this year, we are in the wider than expected range. We think that S&P earnings can be between plus two to plus nine.  because tariff uncertainty is still here. But if we're talking about like structurally, we think that AI just can bring more efficiencies out of the companies.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay, that's companies across the board, the AI companies themselves, effectively the producers. We had someone on the other day who was just discussing AI models and saying, you know, basically, they're kind of all the same.  And in the end, these companies are going to be the AI is going to be effectively like airlines, lots of lots of companies putting piles of capex and producing rather similar products and seeing their margins, you know, never, never quite get where you think they're going to be.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: But also remember, it's also the companies that adopt AI. I think, of course, the discussion is much, much broader than just technology companies. Technology companies are just enablers of that. But I think the adoption will be actually across different sectors.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So will we finally get the great productivity revolution we've been waiting for for decades?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Potentially, yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay, not potentially, yes. Just yes, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We'll see as we go. Depends on how companies adopt an AI.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: OK, so do you still think that in an ordinary person's portfolio, the U.S. should be the kind of weighting that it has been for the last few years? So a lot of portfolios, ordinary people held with wealth managers in the U.K. or elsewhere, et cetera, will have maybe 50, 60, maybe close to 70 percent of their equity allocation in the U.S. Is that still appropriate, do you think?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It's still appropriate to have a very high weighting to S&P, but people should think about how much dollars they actually want to have in their portfolio. Because we're clearly seeing the move over the last decade or so, a lot of investors built very big overweights to the U.S. market and the U.S. dollar.  Now, we're in the camp that we think that dollar will continue to depreciate. For example, we have a target of 120 by mid-2026 on Eurodollar. So that means that people need to start thinking, okay, how do I actually diversify my U.S. dollar portfolio? Now, it doesn't mean that you abandon the U.S. It just means that marginally, you should start looking into other geographies, for example, Europe.  And when you look into Europe, I think... Can I interrupt you just, sorry, briefly?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: When you say marginally, what do you mean? Do you mean that you should take your weighting in the US down to 40%? I mean, how big a shift are we talking about?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: No, I think the shift to 40% is quite substantial. I'm talking about if, you know, investors have 90% exposure to the US. That is pretty substantial, right? If you look into MSCI world, somewhere between 60-70% makes sense to us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay, so just what's in the index? Correct. So anyone who holds a global ETF is already where you would think they should be?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Exactly, because there are people out there who have very big exposures to dollars and to US markets.  And they should start rethinking how much they want to have. 60%, 70% looks good to us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay, and one of the numbers that I keep watching is this number of the percentage of corporate equities in the US that are held by foreign investors. And it keeps creeping up and up and up and up and up. And it's now 17.5%, nearly 18%. And that's up from more like 5%, 6% towards the end of the 1990s. So, you know, it's been a massive shift  by non U.S. investors into the U.S., but you feel that people should be happy with that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, I think, and this is what I mean by marginally reducing the exposures, because if you think about what was the reason for that, it's first of all, a very strong performance of the U.S. equity market, but also very strong dollar. And when, you know,  U.S. market continues to perform really well, but there are question marks around FX. And when other markets are also performing well, back to European domestic story that is happening right now, which wasn't the case, you know, even five years ago, when there is an interesting story here in Europe, then, you know, investors just start thinking about how much they actually want to have in the U.S. if there are alternative markets to that. This is one of the reasons.  The second one is talking, you know, in our outlook, one of the big themes was actually portfolio resilience. So traditionally, people have 60-40 in their portfolio, maybe adding different asset classes, different sources of risk and return to your portfolio makes sense. Infrastructure, gold, hedge funds. So there is a lot to talk about that rather than just having, you know, all exposure in the in the U.S. equity market.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: OK, well, let's go back to when I interrupted you five minutes ago, for which I apologize. You were just starting to talk about European markets and saying that if you're moving a little out of the US, Europe would be one of the top places you would think would be reasonable to go. Is that right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: That's correct. And it's interesting what is happening in Europe, because historically, and I would mean five, ten years, the way everyone looked into Europe was around, well, there is a very good stimulus and strong stimulus in China. Let's buy European equities because they're exposed to that market. Or the U.S. economy is growing and very strong. Europe has exposure to that market.  That is changing. What is happening in Europe right now is you're basically seeing a very strong fiscal stimulus coming from the German market. And just to put some numbers into that, 500 billion over the next 12 years, that is pretty substantial on the economy that is roughly 4 trillion. You compare that to the COVID package back in the US in 2021, similar size, but in a much larger economy. So the impact was smaller and it was quite unprecedented.  Not a lot of people were expecting, you know, something from the German economy, who is in general quite fiscally constrained. So that was surprise number one. And secondly, obviously, the security spending that is coming out of European countries, that is also quite unprecedented. So when you put two things together, you're seeing the growth in the European market that can potentially slightly narrow the gap with the US earnings growth.  Now, we don't think it completely closes. We just think that the gap narrows.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: OK. And that means that it still makes sense for European markets to have lower valuations overall than U.S. markets because that growth differential remains.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And it's not just growth differential, it's also the sector composition. When you look into the discount, Europe in general trades at around 20 to 30% discount to the US. Right now we're at 30%. And the reason is because one of the reasons is because we just don't simply have enough tech.  We have a lot of financials, we have a lot of industrials, whereas U.S. market is all about tech. So naturally, your sector composition is quite different, meaning that your valuation is different as well. Now, in terms of the growth, the growth is also quite different.  But the growth is just the matter of the sector composition that you have. Our tech sector is much smaller than in the US, and therefore our growth is smaller as well. But when we look into 2026 and 2027, so the next two years, we actually think that the growth can be between mid to high single digit.  Now, this year is a bit more uncertain because of the tariffs, but next year, a combination of German fiscal stimulus, security spending in Europe can actually lead to a bit better than average growth in Europe.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: OK, and when you look at Europe, which sectors are interesting?  there's a huge amount of money is going to be going into defense and one of the things that we've talked about again quite a lot here both in the US and across Europe is this changing nature of what defense means and we know when we talk in the UK about spending 5% of our  of our GDP on defense. No one knows where that money is going to come from, obviously, but let's say we somehow find that money. We know it's not actually going to go into, you know, tanks and guns. A lot of it is going to go into energy security and infrastructure, etc. So that's a changing dynamic. Is that a sector that you find interesting in Europe?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We're like industrial sector, so industrial sector is exposed to a lot of different themes and structurally it is interesting. One of the big themes that industrials is actually exposed to is AI. So AI is a big topic and it's not just tech companies that are exposed to AI, it's also the industrial companies. The second thing is you have the fiscal spending in Germany.  So naturally, the companies that are the most exposed to that will actually be industrials. And we think that the impact is likely to come, I would say, from next year rather than this year. Again, this year is more tariff specific. And then, yes, defense spending is also increasing in Europe.  But overall, I would say when you look into the European story, the most interesting angle is actually the domestic companies. Because in the last decade or so, I would say the focus has been on the multinational companies that have exposure to the U.S., have exposure to Asia, but less exposure to Europe. And now it's changing. People want to have domestically oriented companies, either in the industrial sector, financial sector, construction, utilities.  Because again, the story is evolving here in the region, rather than everyone else. And on top of that, you basically have, if you're looking into the domestic oriented companies, you have more exposure domestically, but also less FX risk, which is quite important. Because you know, when euro dollar continues to rise, that is not great for some of the exporters. And secondly, you have less tariff risk.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: What about the consumer orientated companies or even the luxury good companies?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I think the expectations for those companies are quite weak as we speak. I think they need to deliver better than expected results in the coming couple of quarters and especially show that the U.S. market continues to be strong.  And then there is a bit of a relief in the Chinese markets, which hasn't been the case for the last couple of years. I think the valuation is attractive for those markets, but there is a very kind of a big divergence between the losers and the winners in the space. But overall, right now, the market has a bit of a downturn and needs better growth to kind of to show investors that the sector remains to be interesting long term.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Do you look at the UK at all, Natalia? Are you very focused on Europe?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I do. It's a cheap market, but it has been cheap for a very long time. The challenge with the UK is it just doesn't have the same fiscal stimulus as the German economy, for example, has. And as a result, you just don't have the same earnings growth.  as the European markets currently is experiencing. So there are interesting pockets in the markets in different sectors like real estate, some in oil and gas sector, but overall we just can't find the driver for the UK market to re-rate.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: talked about physical stimulus quite a lot. And obviously, the main reason the UK can't have fiscal stimulus is because it's horrific levels of debt and deficit. So, you know, we're not really in a position to spend. And the UK is particularly bad. But across Europe, there's still an ongoing debt problem. Are there any markets that concern you particularly?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: But not really, I would say this is just in general the theme as you highlighted the theme going into this year, we highlighted this particular issue to investors. And look, I think the reason why, for example, Germany was able to do the fiscal stimulus was because they were very prudent for the last  you know, decades or so, when we look into the other countries, it's just much, much more difficult to have a very similar fiscal spending. And frankly, this is one of the reasons why when we talk to investors, we highlight the power of, you know, diversifying beyond your 60-40 portfolio.  adding other asset classes that can do well if inflation picks up, for example, alternatives, for example, infrastructure, hedge funds, gold. So really diversifying given the potential different scenarios that can unfold.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So when you say infrastructure, what do you mean from a retail or ordinary investor's point of view?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It can be just as boring infrastructure as airports and roads, or it can be digital infrastructure that is growing much faster, for example, data centers. But I would say this is probably more a theme in the private markets rather than public markets.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay. And gold? Back in the late 70s, early 80s, it was considered perfectly normal, in fact, even compulsory to have at least 5%, 6%, 7%, 8%, 9%, 10% of your portfolio in gold. And then suddenly, over the 80s, 90s, as inflation disappeared as a risk, so did the gold allocation, and now we're at a point where almost no ordinary investors hold any gold at all. What would you say to them and why?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I would say that investors should definitely have exposure to gold. Gold continues to be one of our highest conviction despite the big rally. It's a different asset class. It provides you with the diversification benefits. And it's also one of the asset classes to look, given the dollar weakness. So absolutely, investors should look into dollar and invest into it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And it's also, I mean, it's your insurance against geopolitics, isn't it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Correct. I would say in general, in the geopolitics, for us, geopolitics tend to have a very short-lived impact on markets. What matters to us usually is earnings. Earnings is the most important factor when investing into markets. And as I mentioned before, this year, we may have a bit of uncertainty given the tariff risk, but overall, we're seeing a very strong corporate backdrop at this point.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: OK, so you are only interested in geopolitics to the extent that you can see exactly how it is that they will affect earnings. It's not so much a sentiment thing for you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Correct. Sentiment can be actually short lived. It was interesting to see the oil price move a couple of weeks ago when oil was trading above 80, but now it's going back to sub 70. And it just shows you that even though the sentiment was rising, but overall, we're not seeing a very big impact on geopolitics right now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah. But it's still, from what you said earlier about the UK market, I picked up that you feel people should maybe still have some allocation to oil and gas.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It depends. When you look into the equity markets and if you're buying the broad exposure, you will have the exposure to oil and gas because it's part of the index. It's just your exposure will be much smaller than the rest of the sectors. Overall, this is not the sector that we currently recommend.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay. And outside Europe and the US, are there any markets that you look at that you find interesting?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We think that in emerging markets, India looks quite interesting. Expensive though. Expensive, but justified. When you look into the valuation, it trades above its five-year average on the P multiple.  But we think it's justified because you have the economy that is growing mid to high single digits. That translates actually into the earnings. Earnings are growing nicely, double digits. Now, it's very hard to find the economies and the markets that are growing so much. And then you also have a very interesting angle, in my view, that is supply chain diversification.  you know when everyone is talking about tariffs and how tariffs can impact different companies, India actually stands out as the beneficiary from all those discussions and diversification of the supply chain and as well can be a market for those who are thinking to diversify beyond United States.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay, any other markets like that? I mean for example we often talk about Vietnam for example as being  a similar kind of economy one will benefit from this diversification of supply chain, etc.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We've been talking about Japan positively, but we recently closed our positive call. We still like it long term. We still think that there are interesting reforms happening in the market. But tactically, we think we can rotate to other markets like Europe or the United States.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And what changed there? Was that valuation based?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Predominantly, yes. It has done well. Valuation is a bit higher than what we would be comfortable with.  So we've been recommending it for a solid time. And we just think that taking some profits never hurts anyone and rotating somewhere else. But this was mainly, yes, the valuation call. Overall, structurally, we think it's quite interesting what is happening there with regards to the reforms and, you know, the increase in the shareholder returns that the Japanese companies are currently going through.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: OK, interesting. Thank you. Now, when you talked about different asset classes making up the 40 in a portfolio and moving away from this whole 60-40 equity bond mix, would you include cryptocurrencies and in particular Bitcoin in that as one of the assets that maybe should make up the insurance element of your portfolio, say alongside gold?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We don't cover it, so we can't talk about it. At all? No.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: OK, I totally understand all your arguments about the US, etc. But nonetheless, if people start investing now and they use the allocation that you suggested as we've been talking, they will effectively be investing at all time highs and at very high valuations. Is there an argument for saying maybe set this out in cash for a while?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I think it's always very uncomfortable to look into the market and just say, it's at an all-time high, I'd better stay in cash. The reality is staying in cash is not great for your long-term goals. Because the equity market is the one that is giving you a very high return over the long term, but it always comes with volatility.  And I would just say that when we do look into our analysis and we compare the investing at all-time highs versus not all-time highs, there is actually not a lot of difference, which is maybe a bit illogical. But the reality is when the market makes all-time highs, the new all-time highs usually follow because there is such a strong momentum in the market. So  Investing all-time highs can be quite difficult psychologically, but statistically looking into the numbers, the returns that you get actually paint a very similar picture if you invest in not all-time highs.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Except for the occasional all-time high. Every now and then there'll be an all-time high that isn't followed by another all-time high.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It's normal to have pullbacks in the market.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, but you just don't know when that's gonna be. All right, Natalia, one final question, if you could. I always ask everyone at the end of the podcast what they are reading at the moment. Are you reading anything interesting at the moment?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Good.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, I would say actually, I'm a big reader of Bloomberg. So I'm not sure if I am your typical guest. I just absolutely love reading what is happening on Bloomberg day to day. This is my my go to source.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

But if you're sort of a  typical investor, you can tune out a lot of the stuff that we're talking about, to be perfectly honest, because, to quote my friend Sam Rowe, stocks usually just go up. And so, you know, it's sort of, you see all this analysis that comes out on the street, like, you know, after the ISM goes to 40%, like, to 40, you know, usually the stock market's higher six months later and 12 months later. Well, yeah, obviously, because the stock market- But that's the default, Sam.

lines.text: I'd say, depending on the decade,  Okay, you're looking at it. It's three out of four or four out of five years.
