video_title: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers Talks Tariffs, Defense Spending | Bloomberg Talks

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Bloomberg Audio Studios. Podcasts, radio, news.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We're just here outside of Durban for the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank meeting that's been going on here for the last couple of days. Wrapping up today, hopeful that there will be a bit of solidarity and a communique coming a little bit later. I'm very pleased to be joined by a guest, Jim Chalmers, who is the Treasurer of Australia. He's come a long way.  for this meeting, so thank you very much for taking the time. Thanks for the opportunity, Oliver. Yeah, I think we have to start with the elephant in the room. Two weeks away from this Trump deadline, what is the status of negotiations between Australia and the United States right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, Australia has the baseline tariff, the 10%, and some additional areas like steel and aluminium, copper, pharmaceuticals, and so we're engaging with our counterparts in the US, like almost every other country is in the world.  We're pretty well placed and we're well prepared to deal with these tariffs. The direct impact is relatively manageable. Our bigger concern is the impact on global demand of all of this uncertainty and volatility and unpredictability, which puts global growth and indeed global inflation at risk. And so in our modelling, the bigger risk comes from the impact on the global economy rather than the direct impact.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Because 10% is basically, as far as we can tell, the lowest possible deal. That's effectively what you'll have with the United States. Are you happy with that? And does that warrant retaliation or no?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We've decided to go for resilience in our own economy rather than retaliation. The 10% tariff is the lowest of any countries.  We've made it really clear that we think the appropriate tariff consistent with our trade agreement is zero. We see these tariffs as self-defeating. We see them as an act of economic self-harm. We've made that very clear. Bad for the US economy, bad for the global economy and therefore not good for Australia. Do you see any progress possible on steel and aluminum?  What remains to be seen, I mean we've been engaged more or less constantly for some months now, whether it's steel and aluminium or some of the more recent announcements around copper and pharmaceuticals. Our approach is to engage at every level as much as we can to get a better deal for our workers and our industries, our exporters and our investors and that approach will continue to guide us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And in terms of the negotiations around pharma, we've heard 200% as a possible figure from the United States. Are changes to Australia's pharmaceutical benefits scheme, is that something that's on the table? Because the Trump administration has been very focused on non-tariff barriers. Is that part of the conversation?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Absolutely zero chance.  We couldn't be clearer. Our pharmaceutical benefit scheme is a crucial part of our architecture, our policy architecture. It's something we're very proud of. We've made it really clear that we're not prepared to negotiate or diminish or weaken the PBS in order to get a deal. We've been clear about that from the beginning.  We're working through the potential consequences of pharmaceuticals being caught up in these escalating trade tensions. We do have quite a substantial export offering into the US when it comes to pharmaceuticals. But how this potential tariff might work, we're working through with the industry and with the administration.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And I'd like to also get your appraisal of the evolution of the multilateral kind of cooperative system, because obviously it's been dealt quite a shock over the last couple of months. You sit sort of interestingly between the nexus of a lot of different sort of spheres of influence. In terms of the conversations that are happening here, how is the G20 and the sort of larger global framework of cooperation dealing with this U.S. situation, and what does the sort of potentially further cooperation look like?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, I've been involved in the G20 in different roles for a big chunk of the last two decades. And we've been through four economic shocks in that period. The reason this one, the fourth one, is different to the first three is that it's primarily induced by policy, by decisions taken around tariffs. And so I think what that means for this type of multilateral engagement  is that people recognise here that at a time when there's lots of volatility, uncertainty and unpredictability, the best defence against that, the best antidote to that is more engagement, more resilient economies, more robust supply chains, more reliable markets for our exports.  And so I think that's really the colour and the context for these discussions. And from an Australian point of view, Australia is a huge believer in multilateralism. We're a huge beneficiary of free and open markets. And so we come to these discussions in that light.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And so, concretely, where do you see the most motion being affected in terms of different relationships with countries, ones that you maybe have not talked to in the same way in the past? How have you seen that changing concretely?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I just think there's a real recognition here that when these tariffs and escalating trade tensions, the uncertainty that comes from that, but also from conflict in the Middle East, conflict in Eastern Europe, a whole range of uncertainty. I think the heartening message from the colleagues here that we've been engaging with is people are not retreating into their own  They're working out how to make our own economies resilient. That's a big part of the Australian agenda as well. But we're trying to de-risk these relationships without decoupling. And I think that's a major theme. It's a heartening theme because the alternative would be to pretend that at a time when these trade tensions are escalating and these conflicts in important parts of the world, to pretend that we can just retreat into our own corners. That, again, I think would be self-defeating. It's certainly not the Australian strategy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And you mentioned defence as one of these sort of issues. There's been a huge amount of pressure from the United States for allies to spend more on defence. You saw that most concretely in NATO a couple of weeks ago, where you had that boost in pledges for 3.5% effectively of defence. Do you think Australia could get to that figure of 3.5%? Do you think that would be appropriate to join sort of allies at that level?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, first of all, it is a big part of the conversation here, particularly with European friends, how they'll find the 3.5% of GDP and how they'll account.  for the other 1.5% of GDP for national security-related spending. For Australia, we are already, by our standards, quite dramatically escalating our defence spending. We're taking it from 2% of GDP up to 2.3% at the start of the next decade. That already represents  tens of billions of dollars in extra investment. It's a much higher trajectory than when we came to office three years ago. And so we are increasing our defence spending. We make those decisions, trading them off against all kinds of other budget priorities. But we say to American friends and we say to the world more broadly, we are already increasing our defence spending because we think it's important at a time where we are seeing this heightened uncertainty in the world.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Given the global volatility, uncertainty and the outlook, how confident are you of your inflation forecast and your growth forecast? How susceptible do you think those are to downward revision?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Look, there's always an element of uncertainty when it comes to forecasting economic outcomes, but especially when global markets are extremely volatile right now.  But one of the things we're very proud of as Australians is there's only two countries here at the G20 that last year had continuous economic growth, inflation with a two in front of it, and unemployment in the low fours. No major advanced economy has been able to, over the last three years, maintain that growth and have those inflation and employment outcomes.  And so why we're proud of that is we've made very substantial progress on inflation, now sustained progress on inflation. It's given our central bank the confidence to cut rates twice already this year. But we've done that without paying for it with much higher unemployment. Unemployment is now 4.3%, historically low, the lowest average unemployment over the last three years for any other  government in the last 50 years. We've created 1.1 million jobs and so our labour market's been a source of strength. We had a little tick up yesterday in the unemployment data but we've got inflation down without paying for it with a big spike in unemployment and that's something we're very proud of.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well Jim Chalmers, thank you so much for your time here on the sidelines of the G20 outside of Durban in South Africa. Thank you very much. So those are the thoughts there from the Australian Treasurer in sort of multilateralism in the age of MAGA and the path forward here at the G20.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The Australian Treasurer emphasises Australia's resilience to tariffs and its focus on global economic stability. He highlights the self-defeating nature of tariffs, Australia's commitment to its pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and the need for more engagement, resilient economies, and robust supply chains amidst global volatility.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The interviewer probes Australia's preparedness for the U.S. tariff deadline, the potential impact on specific industries like steel and pharmaceuticals, and Australia's broader economic strategy in response to escalating trade tensions. He also asks about Australia's defence spending and its role in the evolving multilateral cooperative system.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the status of U.S.-Australia trade negotiations, the impact of tariffs on the global economy, Australia's stance on retaliation and pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and the broader implications for multilateralism and economic cooperation at the G20 meeting.

video_title: Trump’s Financial Reforms: Needed Correction or Ticking Time Bomb? | Trumponomics

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts, radio news.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It's going to be the largest regulatory reduction in the history of our country, and it's going to happen very fast.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I'm Stephanie Flanders, head of government and economics at Bloomberg, and this is Trumponomics, the podcast that looks at the economic world of Donald Trump, how he's already shaped the global economy, and what on earth is going to happen next. And this week, we're talking about Donald Trump's way with money, all kinds of it.  The old guard on Wall Street and the crypto punks are all delighted with the administration's plans for the financial sector so far, especially the big push on deregulation. That's no mean feat. There's little else these folks could agree on. But when the financial sector gets everything it's asked for, that's not always good news for the rest of us. In loosening the guardrails on the banks, or at least saying that's what it wants to do, and giving the presidential seal of approval to all kinds of crypto,  Is the administration laying the groundwork for the next big financial crisis? Or just correcting the mountain of bureaucracy, regulation and risk aversion that descended on America's financial system in the years after the financial crisis of 2008?  That's what I'm wondering about this week, and I have two expert colleagues to help me navigate it all. Joining from New York, Christine Harper, a member of the Bloomberg Editorial Board and also the co-author, with the man himself, of Paul Volcker's biography. And in Washington DC, Katanga Johnson, who's our lead reporter covering banking regulation in that bureau. Thank you so much for coming, both of you. Thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thanks for having us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So Kitanga, we tend to come to the reporters first because they're the ones who are trying to kind of keep track of everything that's going on. When the administration came in, what would you say were their big priorities in thinking about the state of financial regulation in the US and the system that they were inheriting?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: On day one, Trump's regulators really wanted to focus on streamlining all regulatory and supervisory efforts to make sure that small banks, community banks, could compete and that bigger banks weren't necessarily complying with rules that were, as they say, goal-plated or much more onerous than the framers had anticipated.  Part of that focus was really to address things that didn't really address a bank's balance sheet. Things like climate rules, restricting access and partnerships with fintechs and non-banks, a heavier hand on anything tied to crypto. Trump's regulators came in thinking, how can we level the playing field for banks to compete, whether those were smaller banks and bigger banks, and let's pause anything that the Biden administration proposed.  and then revisit some of the bigger ticket items that addressed issues that actually affected their ability to lend, like capital, liquidity, and all the rest.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Okay, so that's really useful. We've tended to think that the administration has acted extremely quickly on an enormous range of fronts in its first few months. If you think about those goals that you just set out, how are they doing? Have they made some big moves in those directions?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: On the one hand, initially, privately, you'd hear folks on Wall Street and even some in Washington would agree there are things the administration's doing that's not quite the main priority that included a flurry of executive orders that seem to get in the way of regulators getting to work. But to some degree, the personnel moves that we've seen at the agencies have really made a big difference in terms of their ability to get the deregulation agenda started. And chiefly,  at the Fed, the departure of Michael Barr, who as the vice chair of supervision under Biden was supposed to be in office until next year, his departure in a bid to sort of avoid a fight with Trump opened the way for Michelle Bowman, who's now the Fed's top bank cop, to come in and really take a look at, okay, what are the main issues that banks have said they want to see paused and what are things that we could begin to do around capital and  the major agenda item so far out of the Fed, and indeed all of the regulators, has been a major capital rule, this enhanced supplement to leverage ratio, which is the beginning of easing capital rules for banks. There are others that we expect, but already having a proposal with a 30-day comment period on that item, in addition to pausing other rules that sort of got in the way, has been in some ways ahead of track for the administration, again, because of Barr's departure.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's good you've taken us to the FED because I want to get onto that a bit later. I think we tend to focus a lot on what's going to happen to the chairmanship of the FED and thinking about Jay Powell and whether he's going to get fired and how much power that might get the president. But as you've reminded us, there's lots of people behind slightly less high profile things that the FED is deeply involved in, which the administration can have a lot of influence over, partly because of that personnel change you just  mentioned Michelle Bowman. So we'll get on to that in a bit. But Christine, after many years of very distinguished reporting in different areas, often in finance in Bloomberg, you're now on the editorial board. And so you're associated with the editorials. And I was quite struck by one on financial deregulation that was published soon after  President Trump was re-elected saying, this campaign's disdain for the administrative state and the public's growing exasperation with red tape suggests the country is in for a period of bureaucratic humility. Here's hoping the financial system doesn't become vulnerable as a result. Well, I think you got the bureaucratic humility right, but do you think overall that we're heading in a direction where the financial system will be less safe?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, it's hard to say. I mean, but as Katanga was pointing out, personnel is really policy here. I mean, besides Michelle Bowman, who's been a very staunch opponent of many of the regulatory efforts under Biden, the Trump administration has named to all of the key regulatory posts people who are, you know, advocates for the industry in one way or another. I think even Michelle Bowman has named one of the top lobbyists for the banks as a key deputy.  So now there are people in position to rewrite or pause, in many cases, rules or enforcement actions that the industry didn't like. That's not always a bad thing. Some of the things that were happening under the Biden administration were just, you know, probably overaggressive. Gary Gensler had an incredible record at the SEC of writing and proposing rules far exceeding his predecessors.  And many of the rules he was proposing were not required by statute. So he was really going above and beyond. And that is all being dialed back pretty quickly. The people who are in place are just right now just trying to end anything that was happening under their predecessors. And as I said, some of that makes sense. For instance, these really onerous requirements on mergers between banks probably don't make that much sense. Bank mergers are in and of themselves not a bad thing. They can actually make the system safer sometimes.  That said, I mean, they basically gutted the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which had done some pretty useful work in protecting consumers. And, you know, it remains to be seen how lowering capital requirements, as they're proposing, will affect the resilience of banks if things go wrong. And then they're dialing back some of the oversight that had been proposed over the sort of so-called shadow banking system, which poses its own set of potential dangers. I thought it was interesting just to make one point that the SEC  One of the commissioners who's still on the commission, who's a Republican, is Hester Pierce. She's so pro the cryptocurrency industry that she's known as Crypto Mom. But she actually put out a fascinating statement last week, pushing back at the effort to tokenize all the financial instruments. If you tokenize things, it doesn't magically change the underlying thing. You can't just avoid securities laws by tokenizing something.  So even people who are industry advocates are starting to see they need to push back a little bit against some of the excessive optimism of the people there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So just to touch into the weeds a little bit, one of the rules that has certainly been a little bit unpopular among some of the big banks is this supplemental ratio, which is supposed to be about maintaining the strength of the balance sheet of the bank and making sure that they can't be too highly leveraged. But there's a change in effective loosening in that, which the administration is very keen to achieve. Roughly, what is that aimed at doing, Katanga?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Roughly, the regulators hope that by making changes to the ratio, to the enhanced supplementary leverage ratio, that trading in the $29 trillion Treasuries market, particularly in a moment of crisis, would be easier for the likes of JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs, and Morgan Stanley. And by lowering that requirement for those banks, it would allow them and their subsidiaries to sort of have the same requirement

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So Christine, I'm remembering in the first Trump administration, some of the constraints that were put on banks after the global financial crisis were pared back. And then it was suggested later that those changes had helped put us on a path to the bank failures we had a couple of years ago. I guess, you know, Silicon Valley Bank, Signature, First Republic. Do you have the same kind of worries about this effort to change the supplemental leverage ratio, or do you think it actually makes a bit of sense?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I mean, it's certainly true that the size of the treasury market has grown dramatically since those rules were first proposed back in, I think, 2014. And so when they were proposed, there was supposed to be this limit on how many, you know, assets banks could have compared to their level of capital, even if those assets were super safe things like treasuries or central bank reserves.  So they wanted to make sure that there was a minimum sort of backstop, no matter what the riskiness of their assets was. But as this treasury market has grown, now the banks are constrained when things really develop from being able to just buy unlimited treasuries. And as a result, you've seen a lot of hedge funds and proprietary trading firms step in and do a lot more activity in the treasury market.  The problem is that if you lower that backstop, that sort of minimum capital requirement for banks, you're just reducing the safety that bank depositors and other investors have that if something goes wrong in the assets on the bank's balance sheet, that they'll have enough capital to deal with it.  So things just go wrong. They always do. And so as a result, it would make more sense, in my view, to have capital requirements where they are. It doesn't seem necessary to lower them. There are other ways you could solve the problems in the treasury market.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It is funny. When you look at a bank balance sheet, there is this kind of basic fact that if it was any other business, you would say it was hugely bankrupt.  It's like they're the only institutions that are able to have a relatively small amount of equity and then they're lending a huge amount on the back of that, which you'd never be able to do if you were just a sort of normal company.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Right. And that's by design. And that's one of the arguments that a lot of the private credit and non-bank companies are saying is that we have a different model where we have more permanent capital.  so there's no risk that depositors suddenly flee and you have a problem with, you know, trying to repay your lenders. But banks, you know, are always going to be leveraged, but making sure that they're not over leveraged is sort of the core part of the post-financial crisis regulation. And so any effort to sort of water that down seems concerning.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Now Katanga, I think, I mean, Scott Besant, the Treasury Secretary, does seem to be one of the key movers in this financial deregulation or certainly to this push to change banking regulation. And of course, the Treasury Secretary has always had quite a lot of power in these areas. But I guess the way that the administration has concentrated power and gained a lot more influence over the independent agencies, you know, Supreme Court has kind of  given them the power to hire and fire many of these officials at independent agencies who we previously would have thought of as a bit more arm's length from the administration. Am I right in thinking that he has become a particularly important figure in this, and along with Michelle Bowman, is really giving the administration a much sort of clearer, unified policymaking than we might have had in previous eras?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You're right, Stephanie. Bessant has really taken the helm of the financial regulators and said, let's coordinate our efforts by meeting with the heads of the three main bank regulators, the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp, and the Treasury's own Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. Together, those three agencies are now trying to coordinate their efforts in streamlining rules, discussing the  sort of priorities around changes to capital.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Call me suspicious, but I can't help noticing that Scott Besant, the Treasury Secretary, who's now going to be also presiding over a massive increase in the number of US treasuries. I mean, the debt is going to go up by several trillion dollars, at least according to almost everyone's forecast.  Is it a coincidence that he also wants to make it much easier for banks to hold treasuries, not worried too much about how many they own? Isn't that going to be on balance sort of positive for the market at a time when the cost of borrowing for government's been going up?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Many people would agree that yes, on its face, it's interesting that Besson is playing that role and seemingly following some strategy that many others either haven't seen or haven't agreed on.  but what the impact will be will be rather interesting, and I imagine in a lot of ways people close to him privately must be discussing, hey, have you considered what the outcome will be by addressing things in this way on both sides.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: That's a very careful answer, which I would expect. I would expect no less. But lots of people would be amazed that we haven't talked about crypto yet. Christine, for people on the outside, that seems like the biggest sort of mood shift and change of direction for this administration when it comes to finance. I mean, that feels like the whole world of cryptocurrencies is being kind of welcomed into the American financial system in a way that was just not the case under the previous administration.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That's absolutely true. And just to return to your previous point about the treasury market, one of the first things that the banking committee got to was the Genius Act, which is a way of creating a regulatory framework for what are known as stable coins. This is a part of the crypto market that basically just is a digital version of the dollar, let's say.  And part of the regulatory regime will require them to own safe assets, like in particularly treasuries. And there's an argument that this will increase demand for treasuries and help the dollar and whatnot. And so you're building sort of a whole financial structure that's even more leveraged on treasury market, so stable coins and banks, as you've talked about, at a time when the treasury market maybe is becoming a little less  reliable, as you just saw a downgrade from the third of the three big rating agencies, that maybe should be a cause for some concern. lines.text: I can't imagine it, but I think, you know, once we get through earnings season, I think the market consolidates probably 3 to 5 percent, you know, over the typical seasonality that we have. And we have to get through that, the impact of the next inflation reports, the next job reports, and what the Fed ultimately does at that September meeting. I don't think there's any chance they're cutting in July.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Right. I mean, he wants mortgage rates lower.  Mortgage rates bottomed just as the Fed began to cut. They were 6-1 last fall.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I know. And let's face it, the biggest reason for the cuts at the short end is the government debt situation, because there's a lot of paper they have to write. So we all know why they need to cut. But my point is that I think there's risk that they're not cutting in September, and that's what we have to get through from a markets point of view into what is a weaker seasonal period of time as well.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Chris, thanks for coming in.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Initiates the discussion, asks about technical standpoints, implied volatility, and the potential impact of a strengthening dollar on earnings.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Provides a positive outlook on the market, highlights solid earnings results, explains the benefits of a weak dollar for multinational companies, and expresses caution about the market's optimism regarding Fed cuts. He suggests that U.S. growth could exceed expectations, potentially strengthening the dollar and impacting tariff effects.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the current state of the market, earnings season, the impact of the weak dollar, and the likelihood of Federal Reserve interest rate cuts.

video_title: Wouldn't Take Much to Tip Labor Market, Fed Gov. Waller (Full)

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Let's talk about why we're losing the luxury of waiting. Have we lost that already?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No, I think we haven't. Like I said last night, the headline numbers for the labour market, what we're seeing, are OK. But it's like when you get underneath and start looking at the data, the private sector is not doing as well as everybody thinks it is.  like most of the half of the employment growth we saw last month was in the public sector. And that means the private sector is not doing particularly well. So I was just joking that, you know, if you're walking on a lake and the ice is frozen and it sounds safe, but when you start hearing cracks, and that's what I feel like, it's too late once you go through the ice. So you've got to start prepping in advance before you have that happen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How do you square that with what we've heard from corporate America so far? What corporate America has told Lisa sitting down with Scott Kirby of United Airlines talking about a rebound in the second half. What we've heard from the big banks so far this week. How do you square what you're seeing in the data with what we're hearing from CEOs?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, I mean when I talk to CEOs I get the same thing. We're in just hold pattern in terms of certainly the labor market. They're not hiring, they're not firing, they're just watching. And that's kind of what you see in this underlying private sector data. There's not much happening. So it wouldn't take much to sort of tip it.  Now, could I be wrong? Absolutely. I mean, last year we got a couple of weak labor market reports that led us to cut in September and then everything kind of reversed and went back up. So I'm not saying that couldn't happen again, but it's just we've constantly seen little bits of data continually coming down. The Beige Book yesterday came out, some other stuff that we get out of the jolts, quits rates, hiring rates. These things are not indicating a super healthy private sector labor market.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: As you know, you're facing potentially, and I stress potentially, negative supply shocks on both sides of the mandate. I want to sit on the labour market just for one further note. Immigration. How are you thinking about that when you look at the labour market at the moment, when we have people coming on the programme, on Bloomberg Surveillance, on Bloomberg TV, every single morning, six till nine, coming on here and saying, look at the data, unemployment could stay at these levels even with job gains of 50,000 to 100,000 because of tighter immigration. How does that factor into your thinking as you look at the US labour market?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, yeah, the labor market doesn't necessarily have to be affected by it because if workers flow in and they get jobs at roughly the same rate as the existing workers, the unemployment rate doesn't change even though the labor force is higher. And when they go back out, the same thing happens. If they leave the employment and leave the labor force, you don't see a big change in  Now, it can potentially affect the break-even rate that you would need to have the market going well. And that's what we're still trying to kind of get a sense of because you basically brought five years of immigration forward and of that eight or nine million most of them haven't disappeared, so they're still here somewhere. Whether they're going to work, they're not going to work, but they're still here.  I don't, where I think the immigration stuff, if immigration was a big factor, you'd be seeing shortages and you might see some in some industries. But like I pointed out, if you look at the new college graduate unemployment rate, it's 7%. It's much higher than it has. These are not jobs that are being opened up because immigrants are not coming in.  That should be just the opposite. If immigrants are leaving and these jobs are open, then the unemployment rate should go the other way. So that unemployment rate, to me, is telling me immigration is not the source of the problem. Firms are just holding off on hiring decisions. Even if their earnings are doing well. That's just what I'm saying they're doing on the Labour side.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I wanted to say there's a mutual friend of ours that feels like he's missing out this morning, so I wanted to catch up with you as well.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: He's out in Victor, Idaho, isn't he?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: He's having a good time, isn't he? Mike McKee joins us now. Good morning, Mike.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Good morning, John, and good morning, Governor Waller. I would say I'm sorry I'm not there with you, but I bet you're sorry you're not here with me. I know you got it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I've been there before. It's a nice place.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You've made the case now a couple of times for a July rate cut, but how committed are you? Are you willing to dissent at this meeting if the majority votes the other way?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I never want to commit to an action before the meeting. Otherwise, if everybody committed before, you don't even need to have the meeting to have a discussion. So the goal is to always go to the meeting, sit down, listen to all sides. People will try to convince me of their view. I'll try to convince them of my views. And in the end of the day, you make the decision on what you think is the right outcome and the right data, how the data is coming in. And right now, I laid out my case last. I don't think I could be any more clear, I hope.  as to what my position is and why I think we need to do this. It's just how I read the data and how I think about going forward, how you respond to anything that involves tariffs.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: There's a lot of politics in this decision coming up, more than usual. And I'm wondering, Governor Bowman has also suggested she would prefer a rate cut in July. If two of you vote for a rate cut, if two of you were to dissent, would you worry about the market reaction to that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You know, one of the things that has always bothered me since I took this job is the criticism that we are nothing but groupthink. All the meetings are the same, nobody dissents, nobody does anything.  And I think this is healthy. I think this is a turning point in the way we want to think about policy. Some people don't want to cut. Some do want to cut. But coming out and making the case either side, that's good, healthy debate. Otherwise, if we're always going to do the same, the joke is why don't you just have one person set policy and send the other 18 FOMC members home?  So this is healthy. I think this is what you want to see in a democracy. You want to see policymakers have serious, open discussion about where policies should go. It doesn't mean anything about politics or anything else. It's make the economic argument and then see if you can convince others to go along with you. And that's all I'm trying to do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We totally agree with you, for the record. We were sick of the group thinking it's good to have dissent. Mike essentially is asking if you will dissent at the end of this month. Is there value in dissenting on the FOMC?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I mean, it's often the case that you dissent if you make it very clear you think at this moment in time this is an important thing to do. If you were to go in and do kind of a jihadist, I'm going to dissent at every single meeting no matter what happens, then you don't even have to show up. Everybody knows what you're going to do.  So it is important to make sure that if you dissent, you do it carefully, and you have the right reasons, and it's not gonna turn into a serial dissenting potential case. I mean, that's how I take my job, seriously and responsibly. So I only would think about doing this, I dissented on the balance sheet slowdown earlier this year because I felt like that was not needed. And that's kind of the situation we're in now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Chris, if you do cut, the markets will go one way. If you don't, they'll go another, perhaps. How critical is it to get to a rate cut fairly quickly? You've mentioned the danger to the labor market. But if you do wait until September, is that going to be too late?  Well, that's kind of the debate.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: What does it mean to wait six weeks? Is it that critical? And the answer is probably not. It could be. But it's also the reverse. Why wait till September if it's just six weeks? That's exactly the thing. It doesn't kind of matter. Just start thinking about, do I want to wait and risk something happening? This is what we saw last summer, by the way. We left July. We left rates. And then, boom, we got a very weak  Bad labor market reports, the unemployment rate jumped two-tenths, payrolls went way down from where they were, and people were screaming at us last August, you guys should have cut in July. So, one month can, it always is one month, just remember that, it's just one month. But we live in a world in which we have to respond to real-time data to kind of sense of where the economy is going.  And I've always said, if you worry about long and variable lags, which everybody always talks about, the whole point of that is to get ahead of it, not wait for it to happen, and then take a policy action that takes quarters or months down the road to actually have any impact.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: The new worry is tariffs. We've just had a six-minute conversation with you about monetary policy. You've built a case for lower interest rates and no-one's talked about trade or inflation. Two assumptions in your speech yesterday, and I think they're important assumptions. A large share of tariff increases won't be passed through to consumers.  any increase would fade over the next year or so. What data underpins that conclusion?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, one, it's just... First, it's just economic theory. So you put on a tariff. As long as it's a one-time tariff and that's it...  That's a one-time price effect. I mean, this is economic theory. You could not get in any serious economic model persistent inflation from that. You would have to cook up some other amplification mechanisms and that's what people talk about. Wages will start going up and everything will get out of control. You're not seeing that at all. This is just not. Those kind of amplification mechanisms where wage price spirals aren't happening.  Tariffs are a tax. And in public finance, you learn that you may levy a tax on a firm, but who bears the incidence or the burden of that tax? It can be a group of people or one person, not necessarily the firm. So this is what I've heard from a lot of firms. If there's a 10% tax, they'll force their suppliers to eat some of that cost. Workers may eat some of that cost in terms of less hiring and things like that. The firm will take it out of their profit margins.  And then lastly, some of it will get passed on. And as I mentioned last night, I've heard this for months now. The rule is 10% is roughly, rule of thumb is a third, a third, a third. Suppliers will eat a third. Firms will eat a third. Consumers are going to eat a third of that tariff. So if you eat a third of it, and it's 10%, like I've been arguing, this is like 3 tenths of a, 3 tenths on the inflation rate for a few months. And that's it.  And it'll persist if you do 12-month over 12-month. That base effect will not go away for a while, and then it'll just drop off a cliff. So that's why I've been arguing you want to look at like three-month and six-months to see if these tariff effects pop up and then go away. And so that's more critical than looking at 12-month.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yes, but the way the president is putting these tariffs on might not match up with theory, Chris. The Smoot-Hawley tax was passed and came into effect on a certain date. The president has not yet put on most of these tariffs. They're, in theory, still coming.  And we still haven't seen the Section 232 tariffs for the most part, the national defense tariffs that he wants to put on semiconductors and pharmaceuticals, et cetera. So if the process is stretched out, consumers could be hit by a series, an ongoing series of tariff increases. And given what they've just been through, isn't there a danger that inflation psychology starts to seep in?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, that's exactly the point. All my example has been is if you put the 10% uniform tariff on and keep it roughly in that range,  then what I've described is what will happen. If there's constantly a sequence of higher and higher and higher tariffs, then you are going to get this rolling potential impact on prices. That's true. If it's still just a question of delaying it, that doesn't change my argument. Whether you see the spike in July or it happens in June or August or September, when it happens is irrelevant for the economics. That's a non-starter of an argument.  Firms could also just spread it out in smaller increments over several months. The total effect still ends up being the same. They just get there in a later fashion. And it'll be smaller amounts. So the bigger thing is if we just continually get another wave of tariffs, another wave of tariffs, another wave of tariffs, that's when things become more problematic, thinking about what's going to happen with inflation.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You don't think the Federal Reserve should wait. I just want to talk about the experience of last year. I think Lisa's done a fantastic job of covering this over the last six, seven, eight months. The move we saw last year, 100 basis point reduction in interest rates on Fed funds, and then we saw a corresponding move of 100 basis points higher at the long end of the yield curve. Yields down did not happen. It was yields up and mortgage costs up as well. How do you think one informed the other? And how might that shape your approach to cutting interest rates this time around?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think last September there was a lot of, remember, the long-term rates were going down through August and early September. This was not any contradiction of what we were doing. It's just after the September meeting, the data just came back in the opposite way. Growth was up, productivity was up, employment suddenly took back off. And then you have  Real growth expectations being much higher. We were seeing productivity growth and GDP growth at close to 3%. So in that case, long rates go up anyway. So it's not necessarily there was some counter-reaction to what we were doing. I never saw inflation expectations adjust that caused all this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You don't think it was the market questioning your commitment to the inflation mandate?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: If it would have been, you'd have seen it in inflation expectations, in the market, not the Michigan thing.  But we didn't see it. I mean, inflation expectations stayed fairly anchored all through this rise. So I think the increase in long rate was just all the data was coming in for a better, stronger economy. Then we thought it was going to be in September. That's fine with me. Sometimes you're going to do these things taking a shot that I want to make sure we don't have a hard landing. And as I said, with any kind of an insurance cut, sometimes you don't need the insurance. It didn't work out. But that doesn't mean you go back and say, oh, that was a stupid decision to make.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Market-based expectations of inflation. Let's sit on this. There are clear and obvious threats to the central bank's independence right now. Every single day on this programme, we're quoting the president, quoting the chairman too late, and going after lower interest rates. And I think a way that you and I can have this conversation without addressing those calls directly is to think about what's happening with inflation expectations.  Do these threats threaten to de-anchor market-based inflation expectations? And is that something you and the committee might become increasingly sensitive to in the months to come?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, like I said, I look at the... You know, after the tariffs came on, everybody was worried about de-anchoring expectations, particularly after some of these Michigan surveys came out. But when I... I always look at the market-based expectations, cos money... People have money in the game. Firms are making decisions on what their chief economists are saying.  And if those things are wrong they're going to lose a lot of money. So I've always paid more attention. I haven't seen much in the way of market expectations being unanchored in any ways you want to measure them, any forward. Now, in the near term of course they might go up because you would see inflation in the short term.  But in the longer term ones, I'm not seeing it. So either the market is just dismissing all of this as chatter and noise, or at some point if something happens such that it becomes much more serious, then you might see a discrete jump. And then that's going to be a problem for everybody.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: One of the questions that we get all the time, Chris, from people on Wall Street is, or one of the posits they make is that all this criticism of the Fed is hurting Fed credibility and that the next chairman is going to have a tough job because there are going to be expectations for the next chairman set by the White House rather than by the economy. Do you feel that inside the building?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No, to be absolutely honest, we just do our job every day. I go in, I just focus on my work on monetary policy payments and oversight of the reserve banks. That's what I do. I let this stuff go and then just try to focus on my job. And I think that's how all of us are proceeding with this.  I mean, at the end of the day, the president winning, whoever they choose, you're going to have to have somebody that has credibility with the markets. Or you will see, as Jonathan was just talking about, you're going to see inflation expectations spike. You will not get lower interest rates. You will get higher interest rates. This is well known. We've seen this everywhere around the world when this happens. And I know Scott Dessin knows this. So this is not something that is lost on anybody.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You've been nominated by this president for the seat on the board. Yes. You were previously director of research for Jim Bullard way back then. Is it a position you would like? Is it something you would like to do in the future?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Look, in 2019, the president contacted me and said, would you serve? And I said, yes. If the president contacted me and said, I want you to serve, I would do it. But he's not contacting me. And we'll see if he does.  If he says, Chris, I want you to do the job, I'll say yes. But he's not talking to me. So that's it. It's a hypothetical that isn't relevant. That might change, sir.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Mike McKee questions Governor Waller about his commitment to a July rate cut and the potential market reaction to dissent within the FOMC. summary.SPEAKER_02: Governor Waller argues that the labour market data shows potential weaknesses in the private sector, warranting caution and preparation. He emphasises the need to consider underlying data rather than just headline numbers. Waller discusses the possibility of interest rate cuts, stating that he is open to dissenting if he believes it is the right course of action based on the data. He acknowledges the political influence on the Fed but emphasises the importance of making economic arguments and having healthy debates within the FOMC. He emphasises the importance of monitoring market-based inflation expectations and notes that he has not seen significant signs of de-anchoring.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the current state of the US economy, labour market, and monetary policy. The speakers analyse labour market data, suggesting potential weaknesses in the private sector and discuss the implications for interest rates. They also touch on immigration, tariffs, and their effects on inflation and the overall economy. There is a debate on the need for interest rate cuts and the potential risks and benefits associated with them. lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We've got a lot going on. We're going to begin this morning with the increasing pressure on the Trump administration to release files related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The president posted on social media last night that he's directed his attorney general, Pam Bondi, to produce what he calls pertinent testimony tied to the Epstein case. Earlier on Thursday, the White House said it would not appoint a special counsel to review the case.  In a new development here, the Wall Street Journal has published a story. It says that more than two decades ago, President Trump wrote a letter to Jeffrey Epstein that reportedly included an outline of a naked woman and a Donald signature. This was part of a bunch of letters for a birthday. The president has denied writing the letter, calling it fake and threatening to sue the paper. The journal story says that Mr. Trump was asked to contribute to this collection of letters that Epstein's then confidant Ghislaine Maxwell was planning to give to Epstein for that birthday.  NBC News has not independently verified that or seen the letter. Meanwhile, we're also learning more about the president's medical diagnosis. He has a condition that causes blood to pool in his legs. The White House addressed the condition yesterday during its press briefing.  This concern was thoroughly evaluated by the White House Medical Unit. The President underwent a comprehensive examination, including diagnostic vascular studies. Bilateral lower extremity venous Doppler ultrasounds were performed and revealed chronic venous insufficiency. Importantly, there was no evidence of deep vein thrombosis or arterial disease.  We'll have much more ahead this hour on President Trump's medical diagnosis, as well as that latest victory in Congress. But let's begin with NBC News White House correspondent Vaughn Hilliard. We're going to start with the latest in the Epstein controversy. Vaughn, good morning. So first, let's start with this Wall Street Journal article. It was published last night. This is this letter, they say, President Trump allegedly wrote to Jeffrey Epstein. In a phone interview with the journal, the president denied writing that letter. We know he's also threatening legal action in response, something we've seen him do before, of course, to press. What more can you tell us?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right, this is a president that has a deep history of denials. He says that this letter was not written by him, and the caricature of the woman's body that is described in this Wall Street Journal story was not drawn by him. The Wall Street Journal moved forward with the publication of this, despite, as they say, on Tuesday night, they talked directly with the president, who threatened to sue them if they moved forward with publishing their reporting here.  The Wall Street Journal is outlining not criminal activity by the president, to be clear, but suggesting that, as part of the files that the Department of Justice has, as it pertains to its longstanding investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, that there are files that had not been publicly made available at this point in time that pertain to the now president.  At the same time, the Department of Justice has made it clear that they had released previously all information that was relevant, would they say, to any criminal investigations. That is longstanding practice to not release evidence that does not directly implicate anybody in a direct indictment. And so there is a question here moving forward.  as to what other references there may be in files related to the president who had a lengthy relationship with Jeffrey Epstein. But again, it's a question of what may amount to just simply evidence of a relationship, but that is not any—that would not contribute to any allegation of criminal wrongdoing by the president.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Von, the president said, though, he's not planning to appoint a special counsel to review the Epstein case. We heard that from his press secretary. It is something that even some of his allies, quite a few actually, had advocated for. How close do you think we are to seeing any files related to Epstein become public? Are there any legal obstacles in the way? Do you see the White House changing course at all as people, members of his own party, supporters of his, continue to call for this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right. The legal obstacles are not wanting to taint anybody who, again, the Department of Justice did not seek to bring criminal charges against. That there may be individuals that provided witness testimony that was unable to be corroborated that DOJ prosecutors ultimately decided not bring charges against because they didn't have a body of evidence that they found that would amount to worthy of criminal charges. And, of course,  The DOJ and the FBI have outlined that there were more than 1,000 victims of Jeffrey Epstein, and there are sensitive details that have been redacted about Jeffrey Epstein's dealings and relationships, not wanting to reveal the identities of those victims or difficult details from the evidence that was gathered.  These are not just grand jury testimony, which Pam Bondi, the attorney general, indicated last night at the request of the president. She will seek to unseal and release. But this is a question also of other records that may be on hand here. And, of course, this is all part of now many years in the making, an effort by those particularly on the right, allies of the president, to have more records of Jeffrey Epstein involved, but not  under the scope that the president, President Trump, would be implicated in any of this. There was a belief that there was a great cabal of celebrities and high-ranking Democrats that were associates of Jeffrey Epstein and would be found to be a part of this ring and a part of this illegal activity that Jeffrey Epstein had engaged in.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Von, also, I do want to ask you quickly about this, the president's health. He's been diagnosed with what's called chronic venous insufficiency. What are we learning from the White House about the condition and how it might impact his day-to-day work?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: This was acknowledged yesterday by White House Press Secretary Caroline Leavitt after it was documented in that photo that you're seeing here this week, the president with swollen ankles. This is when the valve is around in the lower legs.  have difficulty sending blood back up to the heart. This is also coming after several months of photos have shown the president with bruises on his hands. And earlier this week, it included makeup appearing to cover up one of the bruises, the White House saying that that was caused by aspirin.  to address cardiovascular concerns that the president was taking, and from handshakes with the aspirin, a blood thinner, causing those bruises here. The White House says that there are not any more serious symptoms for the president, that he is not taking any other steps outside of taking the aspirin for this cause here. But at the same time, this is acknowledged by the White House after the questions about these images here came out, Savannah.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: All right, Vaughn Hilliard, thank you so much for joining us on this, covering a lot for us this morning. Let's bring in NBC News medical contributor Dr. Kavita Patel on this. Dr. Patel, good morning. So this is being called a common condition, especially for someone of the president's age. A lot of people, though, might not have heard of this chronic venous insufficiency. First, just explain what it is, if you don't mind. Vaughn did a good job, showed those pictures, kind of like what it can present as. But what exactly is going on in the body?  The vanity did indeed. It is a chronic common condition. About one in 20 Americans actually have this diagnosis especially after the age of 50. And what it really involves are the veins. The veins are the big pipes in your body that bring blood back to your heart. And because of gravity the way we sit the way we stand they have these valves that are pretty tough that go one way always to bring the blood back to your heart over time.  and associated especially with obesity, high blood pressure, and some other common metabolic conditions, those valves can become very weak and blood can unfortunately go the reverse direction and pool. That's why you see that swelling around the legs and ankles. Again, very common and a chronic progressive condition. And what's the treatment for this? How does it impact someone's life?  Right. So the treatment depends on the stages. Let's just assume just based on what the president's physician reported in the pictures that we have that this is probably in the early to moderate stages. This is right at the time where you would do very conservative therapy things like compression stockings. Normally I would tell patients to try to elevate their legs and then to try to ambulate not to sit for prolonged periods of time.  Try telling that to an active president. So in addition to this he might be evaluated. There are medical interventions everything from over from prescription pharmaceutical drugs all the way to more intensive therapies that can be done laser therapy surgeries. But it doesn't seem like the president's condition is advanced enough to merit that. But treatment options abound. lines.text: For the first time in decades, Congress is giving a green light to a White House request to take back funding that had already been approved. This could just be the first of more to come. So in a late-night vote, the House passed the rescission bill clawing back $9 billion meant for public broadcasting and foreign aid programs. Those, of course, are prime targets for Republicans looking to slash spending. News Nation's Libby Dean is live at the White House this morning.  Libby, good morning to you. When's the president expected to put pen to paper on this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, quickly, Markey, he's going to sign this at 2.30 this afternoon. This is a victory for the president, and he wants to sign it into law because he's made these cuts really a top priority, and that's why he's signing this bill into law later today here at the White House. Trump reacting to all of this passing overnight on True Social, writing, quote, House approves $9 billion cuts package, including atrocious NPR and public broadcasting, where billions of dollars a year were wasted. Republicans have tried doing this for 40 years and failed. But no more. This is big.  The cuts include more than $1 billion in public broadcast funding and nearly $8 million in cuts to foreign aid programs aided fighting disease, famine, and promoting global stability. Members of Congress from both sides of the aisle are raising concerns over these cuts. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, one of them, arguing these global aid cuts  will hurt small U.S. businesses and reward our foreign adversaries in the end. Now, the president still able to get this over the finish line ahead of today's deadline, sources tell NewsNation. It wasn't easy, though, in this package. At one point, of course, we saw it get stalled because of this frustration among some House Republicans over the handling of the Epstein case, many within the Republican Party urging leadership to introduce their own resolution demanding the release of the files, members of the Rules Committee eventually coming to an agreement.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We were working on cutting fraud, waste, and abuse, and wasteful spending, and they kept trying to hijack that and derail it and turn it into Epstein hearings. That's not what the subject was. So the Republicans on the Rules Committee, most of them that were present, voted against Democrat amendments to try to hijack that. That was the right thing for them.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So this bill delayed into the evening hours last night over the Epstein controversy. It's clearly hiding this discord that we're seeing within the Republican Party over the administration's handling of those Epstein files marquee.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And Libby, while I still have you also happening today, another member of President Biden's staff will now be deposed in Congress over his mental acuity while he was in office. Tell us more about who Annie Tomasini is and what she could say about the former president.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, there's always the chance she could plead the Fifth Amendment and say basically nothing. But this deposition is expected to happen behind closed doors later this morning, Markey. Amy Tomasini, she's one of those longtime aides to former President Biden and is now the third former staffer to be subpoenaed by the House Oversight Committee. Investigating this alleged cover-up of President Biden's cognitive health, a lot of questions there. And this latest deposition comes after both  Biden's doctor, Kevin O'Connor, and also Jill Biden's chief of staff, Anthony Bernal. They pled the fifth in their own depositions. So we'll wait to see if Tomassini invokes her Fifth Amendment right today. But she is represented notably by the same lawyer that Anthony Bernal is represented by. And as I mentioned, he did ultimately plead the fifth. So we'll see if that past pleading of the fifth is any indication to how Tomassini will handle this deposition with the GOP Oversight Committee members today. Marky.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you for watching. Subscribe below and download our NewsNation app right now on your phone and you will get fact-based, unbiased news for all Americans.

video_title: Mitrione: The Fed wants more data before resuming rate cuts

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How should we interpret these comments from Waller? You know, Fed governor, of course, you have a meeting coming up in July. Also, Waller's been floated as a potential successor to Jay Powell. How do you view it as someone who's a market participant?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We are certainly getting mixed signals as far as what the Fed is thinking and where the path of interest rates may go from here. We saw a little bit of a tick up this week in CPI. But overall, inflation has been relatively tame in spite of the tariffs. So there is some thought that we can move forward and start moving back to cutting rates.  But that being said, we haven't seen much in the way of tariffs, but I think broadly the Fed is going to want to see a couple more months of data to make sure that that's not going to lead to a move up before starting to resume any more rate cuts.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know, I think we all agree we haven't seen a significant jump when it comes to prices related to tariffs, maybe some, you know, some small increases here and there. We're standing out with the note earlier this week, believing that we're just at the beginning of the price increases when it comes to tariffs. With the August 1st deadline just kind of looming right now over the market, how are you viewing the risk of inflation spiking up and also upward moves in bonds?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, there is a lot of uncertainty, of course. The market largely seems to be somewhat shrugging it off and hoping that we'll either get trade deals or there'll be another extension in that August 1st date. Volatility has been obviously a lot less than what we saw back in April with some of this commentary. So kind of looking at that and seeing what happens as we do move there, wanting to pay close attention  to how things are moving forward with tariffs and trade as well as what we're hearing in company earnings and how the existing tariffs are really factoring in to their margins which we really haven't seen an impact thus far.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know we all say the markets are price perfection. Important to note that the Nasdaq and S&P are very close to all time highs right now actually hitting all time highs. What do you think about the tech trade in particular. We just mentioned a number of tech names hitting all time highs right now. Microsoft Palantir Oracle. At the same time we've seen a bit of volatility this week. It was NVIDIA being allowed to share it to sell in China again kind of move all the tech stocks higher than ASML warning about growth move them lower than TSMC moving them higher. How are you viewing that trade right now and just the potential I guess risk when it comes to earnings that  even good earnings won't be good enough similar to what we're seeing with Netflix this morning.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It's certainly a concern. I mean we had such we've seen such a surge especially in the tech names from those April lows. So it's been such an incredible rebound. So we are seeing stretched valuations again there. And that being said I mean if you look at really those those  top 10 holdings in the S&P. There's a lot of concentration there. You know 30 percent at 38 percent of the index really 32 percent of the earnings for the S&P over the last 12 months. But those company and so those companies really are putting up the earnings. But the expectations are high. And even even for companies where we've seen some of those expectations come down I think  the market still wants to see that things are moving forward and they are still spending. We are still seeing a lot of investment in A.I. and CapEx spending on data centers and other infrastructure. So the market is going to continue to be volatile around everything that we're hearing from those companies. But we still do think those are a good place to be invested.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right, you're in a family office. I want to get your take on private market investments or also in investing in the alternative asset managers that could potentially benefit if more private investments are allowed in 401ks. I'm looking at Apollo's chart up 6% this week, Aries up over 3%. Would you, as an investor in a family office, are you more focused on the private investments themselves or the players? Which one do you see as a better opportunity?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Honestly both. I mean the players are certainly and a good investments if you want to invest in the public side. But we do believe in investing in an illiquid investments across the private capital spectrum private equity private credit private real estate and other areas. There is an illiquidity premium. We have seen outperformance relative to the public markets. You know if you look over the long term. So there and there are a lot of opportunities to as far as you know if you're looking to for an A.I. play.  that there are a lot of those companies that are going to be significant players in that space are private. So you have the opportunity to to get into a private equity investment and potentially get exposure that you're not able to get in the public markets.

video_title: President Trump reacts to the House passing $9B spending cuts bill | LiveNOW from FOX

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You're watching live now from Fox and welcome back. I did want to take you out to the nation's capital as we've been following this news that did break a little bit earlier this morning. The House gave final approval to President Trump's request to claw back roughly $9 billion for public broadcasting and foreign aid. That all happened early this morning. We are hearing from President Trump. I did want to pull up this post here.  He posted this to Truth Social just a short time ago. He says House approves $9 billion cuts package, including atrocious NPR and public broadcasting, where billions of dollars a year were wasted. Republicans have tried doing this for 40 years and failed, but no more. This is big.  We're also hearing right now from House Speaker Mike Johnson. Here's what he had to say. President Trump and House Republicans promised fiscal responsibility and government efficiency. Today, we're once again delivering on that promise. The package eliminates $9 billion in unnecessary and wasteful spending at the State Department, USAID, and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. The American people will no longer be forced to fund politically biased media.  and more than $8 billion in outrageous expenses overseas. While Republicans continue to deliver real accountability, restore fiscal discipline, and protect taxpayer dollars, Democrats continue to defend waste, fraud, and abuse. This isn't the end, it's the beginning. We look forward to passing additional rescissions bills throughout the 119th Congress.  And once again, you are taking a live look there in Washington, D.C. And if you are just joining us, here's a little bit more information. The vote marked the first time in decades that a president has successfully submitted such a rescissions request to Congress. And the White House suggested it won't be the last, as we just heard there from Speaker Johnson.  Some Republicans were uncomfortable with the cuts, yet supported them anyways. The House passed the bill by a vote of 216 to 213, and now goes to President Trump for his signature. Opponents voiced concerns not only about the programs targeted, but about Congress ceding its spending powers to the executive branch as investments approved on a bipartisan basis were being subsequently canceled on party line votes.  They said previous rescission efforts had at least some bipartisan buy-in and described the Republican package as unprecedented. No Democrats supported the measure when it passed the Senate 51 to 48 in an early vote on Thursday. Final passage in the House was delayed for several hours as Republicans wrestled with their response to Democrats' push for a vote on the release of Jeffrey Epstein files.  The package cancels about $1.1 billion for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and nearly $8 billion for a variety of foreign aid programs, many designed to help countries where drought, disease, and political unrest endure. The cancellation of $1.1 billion for the CPB represents the full amount it is due to receive during the next two budget years. The White House says the public media system is politically biased and an unnecessary expense.  The corporation distributes more than two thirds of the money to more than 1500 locally operated public television and radio stations, with much of the remainder assigned to the National Public Radio and Public Broadcasting Service to support national programming. Democrats were unsuccessful in restoring the funding in the Senate. Lawmakers with large rural constituencies voiced a particular concern about what the cuts to public broadcasting could mean for some local public stations in their state.

summary.Donald_Trump: President Trump celebrates the House's approval of the spending cuts package, particularly the reduction in funding for NPR and public broadcasting, which he believes is politically biased and wasteful. He sees this as a historic achievement after years of Republican efforts to cut this funding.
summary.House Speaker Mike Johnson: House Speaker Mike Johnson defends the spending cuts package as a fulfilment of the Republican promise to deliver fiscal responsibility and government efficiency. He argues that the cuts eliminate unnecessary spending, protect taxpayer dollars, and accuses Democrats of defending wasteful programs. He also hints at future rescission bills.
summary.SPEAKER_00: The news anchor reports on the House's final approval of President Trump's $9 billion spending cuts package, highlighting the key areas of funding reduction, including public broadcasting and foreign aid. The anchor also mentions the reactions from President Trump and House Speaker Mike Johnson.
summary.high_level_summary: The House has approved a $9 billion spending cuts package proposed by President Trump. The package reduces funding for public broadcasting and foreign aid. The move is seen as a significant victory for President Trump and House Republicans, who have long advocated for fiscal responsibility and government efficiency, though it has faced opposition from Democrats and some Republicans.
