lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You've been doing national media.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I know, hate it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: For this book. Senator Murkowski is notorious for sticking to the Alaska Press, talking to the people back home, and not doing as much national media, and so the national media has been thrilled to talk to you in the last couple of weeks. And there are a couple descriptions that keep emerging about you, your independence, moderate is a word used a lot, also lonely is a word that comes up, and we'll talk about that in a few minutes, but I wanna stay in this idea of independence.  and dig into that, because you write in your book about the 2010 election, which went down in history because you won a write-in vote. This hadn't been done since the 50s when Strom Thurmond did it, because a candidate had died, so people wrote his name in. But you also write that leading up to that race, where you lost a primary to a Tea Party conservative, it's like the harbinger of what is to come.  It sounds like you felt like you were drifting away from your authenticity a little bit leading into that race. I mean, I remember talking to you in the halls and you were very much like of the Republican Party line, towing the line. How did you find yourself again in that moment?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think it was not in that moment that I quote, found myself.  It was really when I was defeated, as you've noted, by a Tea Party opponent who,  who presented himself at a time when we were seeing the Tea Party movement really just start to gain a toehold. For the political junkies that are here, the first casualty in the Senate was my friend Bob Bennett, a great, great gentleman.  He'd been in the Senate for a long while. I thought he was pretty conservative, but he was not conservative enough for those in the Tea Party movement there in Utah. And he was defeated in his primary. And he gave me a warning. He said, Lisa, they're coming for you next. And I said, no, no, no. Bob, you don't know Alaska. We're fine. We're fine.  Ah, we were not fine.  And it was a combination, I think, of the movement taking hold, really kind of catching fire in a place like Alaska. But also, I do hold myself accountable for some of that defeat. It was 10 days before the election that my friend and mentor,  Ted Stevens, who had been in the Senate for 40 years, he went down in a plane crash in Alaska along with six others. I lost six friends in that crash. The state went into a period of literal mourning.  went dark with my campaign, as I rightly should. But it was a hard time personally, because there was so much that you needed to do, but out of respect for this extraordinary leader and all those who perished in that crash, the right thing to do was what we did. And there were consequences to that.  And that resulted in a loss. And so it's one of those where you say, I can't say the election was stolen. It was not. I lost that primary. And any good incumbent or candidate would say, OK, you lost.  You're packing. And I said it. I said it. I said I was ready to get my season ski pass at Alyeska. And then strange things started to happen. Alaskans said, we want another opportunity at this. We want an opportunity to participate. And voter turnout had been very low.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It was like summer in Alaska.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, it's the third week in August. The fish are still in the rivers. People have better things to do. Kids are starting school, and nobody's really paying attention to the election. But we also had a closed primary at the time, and so many people said, I couldn't participate, or what was worse was those who said,  I didn't think you needed my help. You had money in the bank. You had good poll numbers. And you'd been there for a term and a half. We didn't think that there was any jeopardy here. That's not good. But Alaskans just didn't let me drop it. And I had to listen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So Sarah Palin comes from Alaska. She's part of this populist Tea Party movement. Joe Miller is part of this populist Tea Party movement. You've been warned by Senator Bennett, and then you pick up the phone and you warn another Republican, a guy running in Delaware. Mike Castle. Who was running there against a woman named Christine O'Donnell. Y'all may remember her. She beat him, and she ended up losing in the general. She had to do that commercial that said, I am not a witch.  never a good commercial to have to run. But it was really like the first stirrings of this populism. How do you see populism factoring in now that Donald Trump has won a second term, that you are seeing this real populist movement in Alaska, other places as well? How do you square that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I think we see that translated in  in really the MAGA movement that we see in place today. So to your observation, I think it all began back there in 2010.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So I brought another visual aid. Murkowski.  Slightly challenging name to get people to spell on a ballot because they had to fill in the oval, they had to write the name. So one of the things the campaign did was made these wristbands, like the Lance Armstrong bands, where people, because you couldn't bring in like paraphernalia into the voting booth.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No buttons, you couldn't bring buttons in.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So these were the wristbands that the campaign used. And you now have a gold bangle that corresponds to that, right? That's like the...

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So mine still says Lisa Murkowski. Fill it in, write it in, because that was the jingle. But the real story behind these bracelets, Vern and I were sitting at an airplane hangar at the memorial service for the pilot that had perished in the plane that Senator Stevens and his group went down on.  And at that service, they had passed out rubber bracelets that had his name in memory of. And Vern was just sitting there kind of twiddling it, because we'd been talking about how are we going to  how are we gonna teach people to spell Murkowski nine letters? Not that nine is hard, but is it with a Y at the end or an I? Is it an E, M-E-R, M-U? Now I'm confusing all of you. But I mean, this was something that we were really challenged with. And Vern looks at that and he's like, how about if we put your name on it?  And we had to teach people that not only did you have to spell the name right, but you had to fill in the bubble next to the line that said write in. Because if you wrote my name in perfectly,  But you didn't fill in the oval. It didn't count. So this was really an education process. So Vern, who is my apolitical political advisor, was the one that came up with these bands. So between my mother-in-law and I designing the button and the wristbands, why did we need an ad team? But don't tell my ad team that. They did a great job.  Did Vern give you that bracelet after you won reelection? Yeah, Vern turned my plastic one into gold and I've worn it every, I don't take it off since 2010. It's my reminder, it's my reminder of how I was returned to this place.  and to the task in front of me, but also kind of who returned me. I'm still a Republican. I was a Republican in that write-in, but I was not the Republican candidate. The Republican candidate had beat me, Joe Miller. And so I just ran as Lisa.  And so the person who was filling in that bubble, writing in that name, very affirmative act of voting. There was no lesser of two evils. You had to really want me to be returned in order to do that. And so the host of different Alaskans that  that engaged in this very affirmative act. They were, yes, Republicans, but they were Democrats. They were independents. They were nonpartisan. They were, you know, none of your damn business party. They were Alaskans that returned me. And so I've been challenged on this. You know, you don't necessarily toe the party line. You know, you're not, quote, always a good Republican.  But I have said my obligation, my responsibility is not to my party, it is to the people that I serve. And it is, it's just, it's my North Star. It's what guides me. And so I have to follow that.  And I gladly follow that, and I think that has given me, back in 2010, given me that real purpose and mission in never forgetting who I serve and what they have asked me to do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: How rare is that feeling of independence, do you think, in the Senate right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You know, it's hard for me to speak for others or to be critical or to say my way is the best way. I just have to approach it the way I feel comfortable. And sometimes, believe me, it is not comfortable. I've got refrigerator magnets that remind me that  Life begins at the edge of your comfort zone, and I'm always like right on the edge there. But it's the responsibility that I have. It's the trust that has been placed on me, and I take it very, very personally. I work hard.  The easiest thing to do in this job, I can tell you, the easiest thing to do would just be to take your party talking points and just follow the line. Then you don't have to agonize over decisions. You don't have to bear the weight of I'm going to listen to all sides. I'm going to entertain the views from all groups.  It's a hard job, but it's an important one.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I really felt for your staff at moments in this book, because you would have these nights of, like, I will or I won't. I'll vote this way. I won't vote this way. Surprise, guys. I've thought about it some more.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Staff, kudos to you guys.  C-SPAN's Afterwards podcast continues in a moment. Now back to C-SPAN's Afterwards podcast.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: There's something liberating in that independence, but there's also something that makes you at the center of the storm, which we witnessed earlier tonight. You are someone that people think that can be persuaded, swayed, convinced. You could go towards the Democrats. You could stay with the Republicans. What is that like, and how do people convince Lisa Murkowski?  that they should be listened to.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, you ask, what does it feel like? Do your kids have one of those Gumby dolls where you just kind of pull them? You know, I joke about that. It's not comfortable to be in hard conversations. But this is not designed to be easy.  I mean, nobody promises that when you become a United States Senator, that somehow or other, the higher up the elected process you go, things get easy. It absolutely is not. And so,  you know, how do you influence me? Facts. Facts really help. Sticking with things like the rule of law matters to me. Some constitutional provisions matters to me.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So.  One decision that you agonized was whether or not to vote to confirm Brett Kavanaugh to be a Supreme Court justice. And I was covering this live at the Washington Post, and as soon as he started yelling, I actually turned to a colleague and said, I think they just lost Lisa Murkowski. And then you agonized over this decision for a long time, but you could have just called me and I probably could have told you how you were gonna vote.  But there was a temperament issue there, and I know you well enough to know what you think. I mean, you're a lawyer, a trained lawyer. You went to law school before entering politics. You had a whole life before you entered politics.  You also were probing, of course, quite thoughtfully and carefully what it meant to have Christine Blasey Ford come forward and talk about her allegations against Brett Kavanaugh. Your office was inundated with calls. You were crushed by throngs of people in the halls of Congress. You were meeting upon groups of women who were telling you their own stories of surviving sexual assault. You even talk about your own personal experiences in the book.  So what gave you the courage to go out on that limb and be the only Republican to say, I don't feel comfortable with this nominee at this moment?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, and again, it occupies a full chapter.  because it was not an easy decision. Justice Kavanaugh clearly had the legal background. There's kind of a list of things that you go through when you're considering a judicial nominee, and when you're considering a nominee to the highest court in the land, you have to take this role of advice and consent very, very carefully, right?  And so I did agonize over it because I saw, just as you have shared here, there was an issue with judicial temperament.  People need to know when you're going before a court that the judge is going to be able to be not only free from bias, but really keep their own emotion and personal views certainly below the bench, right?  That was one aspect of it. But as I share in the book, I wanted to make sure that Justice Kavanaugh also had an awareness that what the country was going through as a consequence of these hearings, watching Christine Blasey Ford give her testimony,  And then seeing this movement, I mean, it was the Me Too movement where you had women that were stepping forward with personal stories of their own that perhaps they had not shared previously because they felt they would not be heard.  or they had shared it, and it went nowhere. And so there was this kind of a confluence where it was not just about the qualifications of a nominee, but it was what had been evoked among so many women in this country, all coming to the surface at the same time.  And so I asked for a one-on-one meeting with Justice Kavanaugh and had a very direct conversation, which to this day I deeply appreciate. But I came to the conclusion that he was not aware of what  what so many were going through. And you can't say, well, you are a man who has not have lived experiences. But to have a level of awareness as to what the country was experiencing was what I was trying to evoke from him.  It is, to this day, one of the decisions that I have made that has brought about as much introspection, reflection, truly, in terms of due diligence, and trying to  to make the right decisions for the right reason, that was one of the most challenging ones in my career.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I want to talk about loneliness now, because in the early days of the Senate, you had a group of women who would get together. It was like the Mikulski rules. Barbara Mikulski was like, you couldn't, no staff, no notes, you couldn't leak anything. It was just women from both parties getting together. She was a senator from Maryland, Democrat. The dean of the women.  women in the Senate, Barbara Mikulski. You've had other strong relationships in the Senate, people you've worked with. Alaskans cringed when they read about Mitt Romney, when McKay Copkins wrote the book about Mitt Romney having a freezer full of salmon fillets from you, like precious Alaskan salmon, and he didn't like it and was putting it on buns with ketchup.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: He said he liked it, he just liked it with ketchup, which is...

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Who puts ketchup on their Alaska salmon? Who do you hang out with now? A lot of the people who you have found relationships with in sort of the moderate wings of both parties, the Joe Mansions, the Mitt Romneys are gone.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I wish that I could say, well, I hang out with so and so. But in fairness, we just don't hang out. Maybe it's because we're getting older. But there's just so much that we've got to do. But one of the things that- Are you finding people to do things with?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: To accomplish things right now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yes, yes, we don't have our, like our gang of 10, our gang of eight when we were working on the infrastructure bill, but we are working on some initiatives, and those are good, those are important. But one of the things that you speak about was the Women Senators Dinner.  That was really, there was such value in that because what it was was the women coming together, the Republicans and the Democrats, and sometimes there would be six of us, sometimes there would be a dozen of us, but we'd usually have a dinner, somebody would host, sometimes it would be in your home.  sometimes it would be over in the Senate, sometimes it would be a restaurant. And we would just talk as women, women with interesting jobs, but we didn't have to talk about our jobs. Sometimes we talked about how the place would run if we were running the place. Those are always fun conversations. But we haven't been doing enough of those as we should. And I think they're valuable because you do form friendships.  where we have that commonality of we all have a hard job, we all have awful schedules, and we all ask our families to just take on so much of the burden of unknowing, not knowing when we're going to have recess, when we're going to be coming home for dinner, and it's just hard.  And I think most would acknowledge that there is kind of that loneliness because you don't have the time for that socialization. And so for me, it really is, it's my family. My family is what gives me the anchor, keeps me humble, and is the best part of everything I'll ever do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I'm going to transition to some audience questions now. We got these in advance from people who are here in the audience and those who are attending virtually. And this first one is something that I also would love to hear you talk about. Leone writes, you recently went viral when you said at a conference, we are all afraid.  What did you mean by that? And what do you tell your constituents who are afraid of the direction that the country is moving under the Trump administration? And give us the context. You were talking to a group of nonprofits in Alaska, hundreds of them, but these comments really exploded because people latched onto it. People connected with it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So this was a couple months ago, and I was home in Anchorage, and I was speaking to a group of nonprofits. There were about 500, maybe 550. It was a big group. And it was just at a really stressful time. What was going on, this was, you know, many of the federal employees that were probationary had been told, you're fired, you're out of here. And then they were kind of brought back on because of,  legal challenges. There was great uncertainty. We'd already seen a significant round of rifts, reduction in forces, and so that was a challenge. There was a pause on everything that was going on. Now keep in mind,  Alaska has more federal employees per capita than just about any state outside of Maryland and Virginia. And it's not because we asked for it. It's because we have 60% of our lands that are federal lands.  17% of our population is Alaska Native. So you have IHS and BIA. You have more national parks, more acres of Forest Service land. And so how more veterans, we've got all of our military installations. So we see a lot of federal employees, but we also see a lot of federal programs. And so when everything is in limbo,  you can't get information about whether or not the grant that you have to help you with your woman's shelter is going to come through so that you can make payroll for the next month, and you're not sure whether you can even take in any more women to the shelter, and you don't know where to go.  you go to your senator. And there was so much anxiety with everything that was happening in the state. It was palpable. I'd walk through the airport, and people were like, can you help me with, we've got a small hydro project down in Southeast, and we've been fighting for years to get it, we have the money, and now we can't get anyone to return a phone call. It was,  It was a time for us in our office where there was nobody that was not literally working casework around the clock trying to get answers. And everyone was afraid. Is this going to be the end of what I'm working on?  What's happening next? Am I going to be able to keep my job? And that's all I kept hearing. And I didn't have any answers because we were trying to get answers as well from the administration. Everybody was kind of drinking out of a fire hose. And sometimes when there is great anxiety, the most helpful thing that you can do is just listen and let people know that I am listening to you and I'm going to try to help.  But I also had to acknowledge that I get it, because I'm hearing it from everyone. I am hearing that you are afraid. And so in that room, and if you watch the video clip that was out there, I think somebody just literally took a handheld, but it was, I paused. I paused.  few seconds, maybe more. And I said, look, we're all afraid because of the uncertainty. And I didn't say because of the uncertainty. I just said, we're all afraid. That was that viral moment. And then I went and I went on further.  Because in addition to all that kind of uncertainty, what we are also seeing at the same time was we were seeing things coming out of the administration that, in my view, were absolutely unprecedented. When through an executive order, you have literally a blacklisting of law firms because of who they had represented  post-January 6th. To me, that, if that isn't retaliation, I don't know what other word to call it. And so I was speaking truth to what we had all seen, and yet it hadn't been, it hadn't been expressed, um,  Outwardly, it certainly hadn't been expressed by a Republican, and so I said what I felt needed to be said, and that was that viral moment.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: How do you get, I'm just gonna add on a little quick addendum to this, and we'll get back to the audience questions. Why would someone get involved in politics right now? How do you get people, because I think when people heard that quote of you saying we are all afraid, people heard from it what they were feeling. And some of that was about the fear of retribution, but even the fear of safety, the fear of speaking out, the fear of finding your voice. We just saw this horrific murder of a Minnesota lawmaker and her husband.  It was the hit list, I have a former colleague who was on the hit list, who now is in public service and just trying to make a difference in her community. So what, your message in the book is so much about.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It's supposed to be about hope, right? Yes, yes, yes. And getting everyone to be involved in your PTA. Yep, yep. We are,  America, where this open and free society, right? I wish that I could say we lived in a place where we were free from violence and political violence, but that is not our reality. We have gone through some very difficult times as a nation, and probably some that have been more volatile than we are seeing now.  but it is how we condemn it and how we roundly condemn it. All of us, it doesn't make any difference if, it doesn't make any difference what the politics were of somebody who has been made a victim as to whether or not we are, express our sympathy and our care  At the end of the day, this is about treating people with respect and dignity. And we as lawmakers need to ensure that we are doing our best to not fan the flames, to not be a participant in these things that ignite and instigate, whether it's violence or just  further disruption that is harmful. And so how do you dial it back? I think that really is up to us. And it's not just up to us as lawmakers. I mean, we're seeing this at the local level. We're seeing it translated so that nobody wants to be on the school board because people are getting angry and shouting and, you know,  wanting to ban your books or whatever it may be, but I reminded somebody as I was talking last week, I said, you know, don't be afraid to involve yourself in these acts of civic responsibility.  And do it for the right reason, not because you want to ban a book, but because you care about the school. You care about your community. And if you're doing that, if you're doing it for the right reason,  The ones that are going to be loud and bombastic and just want to be there to make the evening news, maybe they will actually get tired of the hard work that actually comes with creating a budget for your little school district or helping  to navigate through your local PTA issues. But we can't give up. We can't say it's just too hard. We can't say I don't want to do the extra work. Because when we do that, who loses? Our community loses. Our family loses.  We need to believe that the differences that we can make are worth some of the inconvenience, some of the sacrifice, but we have to believe in ourselves and what we're working for.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Question from Phoebe. Okay. Thanks to your book, we are gathered together to engage with neighbors and strangers. These kinds of connections can be in short supply these days. How can we support the nation's humanities councils as they work to provide opportunities like these with authors and scholars as congressionally appropriated funds are being cut off?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah. It's a great question and it's important because it's important for us to realize the  the richness that comes when we do come together as communities, when we do come together over humanities and arts and the things that make us richer as human beings. And does the federal government have a role in that? I believe so. I believe so.  Of course, but then I'm one who believes that education is not just about reading and writing and arithmetic, as important as all that is. I want to make sure that there is an exposure to the arts, to the music, to building out not only children, but it is something that, again, allows us to be better humans.  and treating one another with greater dignity and respect. And so, is there a role? Yes. This is actually part of the budget that I have as chairman of the Interior Appropriations Committee. Part of that is the NEA and the NEH, National Endowment for Arts and Humanities. And I've been proud of what we have put in place.  to make sure that people have access to these important programs and provisions. And it's not just that. It's libraries. Yes, we have a role as a government.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Nathan asks, what legislation from your Senate career are you most proud of?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: What legislation am I most proud of?  I'm sure people want me to say it's been opening up ANWR. The infrastructure bill, obviously, is one that I'm very proud of because of the very collaborative nature of all of that. The Energy Act of 2020 was, I think, transformative in terms of our energy policies that hadn't been updated in a decade plus. There's so much there, but I'll tell you,  We did something that's called special interest legislation, and it related to a woman who was in Bethel, Alaska, actually.  I don't remember how many years ago. It was some years back. But anyway, it was an immigration issue, and we were able to ensure that she was able to stay in this country with her husband, who was a proud member of the military, and her children. And I think about just the personal satisfaction of knowing that we really helped one family remain together.  It was brief headlines in the Bethel newspaper. You'd never know it back here, but those are some of the things that you think about as really important.  worthy and important because, again, it's about how we're treating one another. And if we can throw in a little dignity and respect, it's been a good day.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Final question from Maya, who asks, in these times of immense stress, what brings you joy?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Ah, what brings me joy? I have to tell you, I start getting a kind of the ability to breathe and put on a smile the closer I get to home. And I tell you, I feel like I can sense it when I'm on the Alaska Airlines jet.  You leave Seattle and it's lovely down there, right? But you can tell when you start getting into Alaska because there the mountains have meaning, man. They are big and hard and raw and everything just kind of opens up and the water is beautiful and the clouds are beautiful and you land and the air is fresh and people  You know, you're walking down the sea concourse there, and people are like, hey, Lisa, how about you have some little old lady come up and give me a huge hug. And I'm thinking, okay, I can't remember her name. And she says, I've always wanted to meet you. Like, she's greeting me like she's my long lost friend.  And it's just, I feel filled up. I feel like my reservoirs are filled up when I am able to be back home. And then when I'm with family back home, it's just right. Senator Murkowski, thank you so much. Thank you. Thank you. Thanks, Judy. Thanks. Thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00

video_title: 'A Government-Issued CBDC Is Nothing More Than An Orwellian Surveillance Tool': Tom Emmer

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you, sir. The whip is recognized. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. After much debate, we can now codify President Trump's effort to prevent the development of a Central Bank Digital Currency, or CBDC, and ensure that the United States' digital currency policy remains in the hands of the American people and not the administrative state.  I'm proud to have my legislation, the Anti-CBDC Surveillance State Act, being considered on the House floor for a vote today. This bill is straightforward. It prevents unelected Washington bureaucrats from creating a financial surveillance tool that, if not done correctly, will fundamentally alter the lives of every American.  Unlike decentralized digital assets, a CBDC is a digital form of sovereign currency that is designed, issued, and monitored by the federal government. It is government-controlled, programmable money that, if designed without the privacy protections of cash, this could give the federal government the ability to surveil and restrict Americans' transactions and monitor every aspect of our daily lives.  In other words, every dollar you spend, where you spend it, who you spend it with, would all be visible to and tracked by the watchful eyes of Washington. There would be no cash, no anonymity, no space for private financial decision-making.  This isn't an inconceivable concept. We have already seen examples of governments developing these types of tools and using them to weaponize their financial systems against their citizens. The Chinese Communist Party employs a CBDC that is being used to monitor and restrict citizen spending. The data is being used to develop a social credit system that rewards or punishes individuals based on their spending behavior.  In Canada, the former Trudeau administration demonstrated the power of federal financial surveillance and control when it froze the bank accounts of hundreds of truckers protesting the COVID vaccine mandate in 2022. Surely, this totalitarian surveillance tool would never take root in the United States.  However, that assumption would be wrong. This is not a theoretical risk. It is a very real and very dangerous precedent. Under the Biden administration, financial surveillance was a core tenet of President Biden's policy agenda. In 2022, President Biden issued an executive order placing urgency on CBDC research and development.  Moreover, the agency reports created under that executive order made it clear that the previous administration was eager to create a CBDC and was willing to trade Americans' right to financial privacy for a CCP-style surveillance tool.  Our bill, the Anti-CBDC Surveillance State Act, prevents future administrations from weaponizing this technology against the American people, while ensuring that any development of digital money reflects our American values of privacy, individual sovereignty, and free market competitiveness. If not designed to be open, permissionless, and private,  private with a capital P, resembling cash, a government-issued CBC is nothing more than a well-in surveillance tool that will be used to erode the American way of life. The federal government has no business monitoring Americans' daily financial lives. We don't need or want a state-run digital dollar with Chinese Communist Party characteristics.  We need to protect the core principles that make this country exceptional. Liberty, limited government, and the right to privacy.  We are on the verge of the next game-changing technological evolution, and we must embrace this push for a more developed digital economy. In doing so, we cannot jeopardize who we are as Americans, and this bill is designed to ensure just that. I want to thank Chairman Hill and Chairman Stile for their tireless work and advocacy on this issue, in addition to the 135 members of Congress who have joined as co-sponsors of our legislation.  I urge all my colleagues to support this bill, and I yield back the balance of my time.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker introduces the “Anti-CBDC Surveillance State Act” and argues that CBDCs could become financial surveillance tools controlled by the federal government. They warn that CBDCs could enable the government to monitor every aspect of Americans’ financial lives, drawing parallels with authoritarian regimes like China and Canada, where such systems have been used to restrict citizen freedoms. The speaker emphasises the need to protect privacy, individual sovereignty, and free market competitiveness and urges colleagues to support the bill.

video_title: Afghan Reprieve & Democrats Storm Out | Bloomberg Law

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: This is Bloomberg Law with June Grosso from Bloomberg Radio.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: A reprieve for nearly 12,000 Afghans. An appeals court stepped in to keep protections in place that have prevented the Trump administration from deporting them. That's at least until Monday, while both sides file legal briefs and the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals makes a decision.  The Trump administration has moved aggressively to remove temporary protected status from Afghans and hundreds of thousands of people from six other countries as part of the administration's effort to ramp up deportations. Joining me is Samuel Siegel.  Senior Counsel at the Institute for Constitutional Advocacy and Protection at Georgetown Law. Along with the Washington Lawyers Committee, it's representing CASA, a non-profit immigrant advocacy group that sued the administration over the TPS revocation for Afghans as well as for people from Cameroon.  So before the appeals court stepped in, the Trump administration had planned to end temporary protected status for Afghans. Tell us about that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So the Trump administration had announced that it was ending temporary protected status for Afghanistan this week. It announced that the conditions that initially led to the designation of that country, the ongoing conflict between Taliban and other insurgent groups,  and the extraordinary humanitarian conditions were essentially no longer so severe that it merited that designation. I guess to take a step back and talk a little bit about TPS, TPS is a status that the Secretary of Homeland Security can designate a particular country for based on certain conditions in those countries, particularly if the country is experiencing ongoing armed conflict, if there's a natural disaster, or if there's another extraordinary condition in the country.  If the secretary makes that conclusion, then he or she will designate the country for TPS, which allows individuals from those countries to live and work in this country for a particular set period of time. Secretary Mayorkas concluded that Afghanistan merited that determination back in 2022 and extended in 2023 based on those conflicts and the conditions in Afghanistan. And Secretary Norm at least purported to say that those conditions no longer existed.  Now, of course, our challenge, one of our arguments is in fact that that purported rationale for the decision is not the one that's actually motivating the actions here. Our argument is that this is a preordained decision as part of the Trump administration's broader effort to reduce the number of nonwhite immigrants in this country. And that's the basis on which we have asked the fourth circuit to pause the DPS termination while the appeal plays out.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Are you also arguing in this that what the Homeland Security Secretary determined, that there are improvements in security and economic situations and that Afghan nationals can return, are you arguing that that's factually incorrect?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We're not making that specific argument in part because of some jurisdictional bars on what the courts are allowed to consider.  I think what we are is pointing to that the conditions in the country are not good, and this further supports the argument that the purported rationales that things have improved are not the actual ones. So it's that mismatch between what's actually going on in Afghanistan and the actions here that support our argument that even if things might have improved a little bit, that's not really the reason that she's doing that. And I will just note to this effect, you know, as part of the litigation here,  The administration had to produce an administrative record, which is all the things that were in front of the secretary when she made her decision. And in November of 2024, the U.S. Customs and Immigration Service, which is one of the entities that typically consults on these, concluded that, and I'm going to quote here,  Quote, Afghanistan's civilian population faces dire challenges, including a collapsing economy and health care system, ubiquitous food insecurity exacerbated by drought and widespread insecurity due to decades of armed conflict and insurgency that is entering a new danger phase. It also stated that the Taliban authorities violently target citizens and foster continued armed conflict and interethnic strife.  and that it imposed restrictions on education, employment, and other areas on women that foreclosed their ability to make meaningful participate in their country. So again, we're not necessarily challenging the underlying factual conclusion of what's going on here, but we're saying that these kinds of statements from the federal government itself demonstrate that there's really something else going on here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So, Maryland Federal Judge Theodore, so Federal Judge Schwong allowed your challenge to TPS to go forward, but he declined to halt the administration's policy and, you know, preserve TPS protections. He found that your group hadn't established sufficient likelihood of success on the merits. Will you explain why he thought that you wouldn't succeed on the merits here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I think Judge Chuang issued a well-considered and balanced opinion. He concluded, as you said, that our challenge can go ahead, notwithstanding a couple of jurisdictional arguments that the defendants had raised. And he also concluded by pointing to things like the U.S. Customs and Immigration Service report that I just quoted, that we had plausibly alleged that the action taken with respect to Afghanistan is part of a broader policy to reduce the number of non-white immigrants in this country.  and to effectively terminate almost all TPS designations. But then he said we had not yet introduced enough evidence to sort of get over that likelihood of the success on the merits hump. And so there's some delta there in his mind that we hadn't yet demonstrated that we could get there. And he said, look, I'm going to allow this claim to go forward. You all can go into discovery and try and identify additional evidence that will support your claim here. But at this point, I'm not  going to enter relief. So we respectfully disagree with that part of Judge Chuang's ruling. We think that the allegations that we made here and the evidence before the court was sufficient to, at a minimum, temporarily pause the termination of Afghanistan's TPS designation while we get that discovery, while things play out. And that's sort of the similar request that we've made of the Fourth Circuit, is just to postpone this agency action while the appeal plays out.  And one thing I'll just note here, you know, Judge Chuang noted that other courts have entered preliminary relief of some sort in response to similar claims and similar amounts of evidence in the past in the first Trump administration and said, well, we hadn't produced enough evidence here. I think it's important to note that in those cases, the time between when the end of the TPS designation was announced and when it took effect was in most cases more than a year. So those parties had  you know, much more time to produce the kind of evidence that Judge Chuang is asking for. When we're asking for just this sort of temporary relief while things are playing out to their merits, we think that, first of all, the evidence that we have produced and the things that we've pointed to, like the thing from USCIS that I pointed you to, like some other statements from President Trump and Secretary Nome,  demonstrate that this is part of a preordained effort and demonstrate that we will likely succeed on the merits when we get there, especially as we get into discovery and produce more evidence in support of our argument.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So the Fourth Circuit gave you an administrative stay for a week. What's happening in that week?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Right. So for right now, as you mentioned at the outset, the Afghan TPS designation was set to expire on Monday. In the interim, the court has asked us to brief our request, formally called a postponement of agency action pending appeal.  The federal government's brief is due by 11.59 p.m. Eastern tonight and then we have 24 hours to return around a reply and then we'll get a decision presumably at some point before next week Monday at 11.59 p.m.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Is this a losing battle in the end because if and when it reaches the Supreme Court, you're not likely to find a receptive audience, at least among the conservative justices? lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So I don't want to make too many predictions about exactly what the Supreme Court is going to do here. I will say that we're very confident in our case. And I'd just like to parse out those prior grants of, I think, stays of lower court's orders.  With respect to the Cuban, Haitians, Venezuelans and Nicaraguans, that was actually with respect to a parole program that had been adopted by the Biden administration. So it didn't involve temporary protected status. And I think, you know, sort of trying to extrapolate what the court said there and apply it here, I think is a very difficult thing. Similarly, with respect to the Venezuelan program, that was with respect to the temporary protected status.  But in that case, the arguments that were being made were different from the ones that are being made here. There, for example, the plaintiffs argued that Secretary Mayorkas, who had extended the TPS designation for Venezuela for about 18 months at the end of the Biden administration, and then Secretary Nome had revoked that extension. I mean, with Afghans in particular, we're talking about individuals who served our country. One of the members of CASA, who's our client here,  is a person named B.S. who faced death threats due to her work as an interpreter for international United States agencies. And she's fearful that if she's returned, she's going to be targeted by the Taliban if she goes back to Afghanistan. So, again, I think it's always a little bit of a hazardous proposition of guessing what the Supreme Court might do if we get there. But we think that we've got a very strong case and that what the court did with respect to Venezuela and with respect to the parole program doesn't shed all that much light on what it might do here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So can some of the Afghans that you're representing apply for special immigrant visas or asylum?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Some may be able to, you know, but I think it's important to emphasize here that TPS is, you know, the bird in the hand. It guarantees them the ability to be in this country. It guarantees them the ability to work in this country. It guarantees them under the statute they cannot be put in detention on the basis of their immigration status.  Things that may not apply to everyone that is securing or in the process, at least, of securing relief through other means. So there might be other things that are available, whether or not they will ever be able to take advantage of those status. Who knows, especially as this administration has assiduously worked to make those kinds of relief further out of reach.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: One of the things the White House press secretary said was that temporary protected status was never intended to be a de facto asylum program and that it's not supposed to be renewed over and over again.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I think that's certainly right. I mean it's baked into the name temporary protected status. But there are.  specific criteria that the secretary is supposed to analyze in good faith in determining whether or not to designate a country in the first place and to extend, including, for example, whether or not there's an ongoing armed conflict there. And when the secretary offers reasons that are contrary to one or offers reasons that are pretextual, we just don't think that that's a basis for being able to terminate a TPS protection. And if she makes a good faith assessment,  then this can be terminated. And TPS designations have been terminated in the past. Just hasn't done what the statute requires in this instance.

lines.text: The prison, a character on film, perched on an island off San Francisco, a fortress with a reputation for being impossible to escape, opened in the 1930s, no more than 275 inmates at any time. In its day, the Federal Bureau of Prisons said inmates at Alcatraz had only four rights,  food, clothing, shelter, and medical care. Everything else was a privilege that had to be earned. Over the years, the maximum security prison held some of the most recognizable names in criminal history. Al Capone, George Machine Gun Kelly, and Robert Stroud, the so-called Birdman of Alcatraz.  In the 29 years that it operated, escapes were attempted and documented 14 times, but none was successful. Though some did get close, as dramatized in the 1979 Clint Eastwood classic, Escape from Alcatraz.

: TSA security changes at US airports announced by DHS Secretary Kristi Noem, aimed at enhancing efficiency and reducing invasive procedures; President Trump\'s health update following an impromptu examination revealing chronic venous insufficiency; and political discussions on border security, with notable drops in encounters and fentanyl seizures, and the potential reopening of Alcatraz as a symbol of law and order.', 'SPEAKER_04': 'Blake Berman moderates the discussion, highlighting these developments and their political implications.', 'SPEAKER_02': 'White House Press Secretary Caroline Leavitt discusses President Trump\'s health and the administration\'s successes at the southern border.', 'SPEAKER_01': 'DHS Secretary Kristi Noem announces significant changes to TSA security protocols, including the possibility of relaxing liquid restrictions and introducing dedicated security lanes for military members and families.', 'Donald_Trump': 'Trump discusses his health, the potential reopening of Alcatraz as a symbol of law and order, and emphasises the need for strict border security.', 'SPEAKER_03': 'Julia Manchester and other panellists discuss the political implications of the border security measures and public opinion on immigration.', 'John Pistol': 'Former TSA Administrator John Pistol supports the review of TSA security measures, noting that some protocols like the 3-1-1 liquid rule are outdated.', 'Sean Spicer': 'Sean Spicer defends the idea of reopening Alcatraz as a symbolic measure to enhance border security and emphasises the decrease in border crossings under the Trump administration.', 'Tracy Walder': 'Tracy Walder expresses scepticism about reopening Alcatraz due to practical and staffing challenges.', 'Charles Marino': 'Charles Marino criticises the practicality of reopening Alcatraz for current immigration needs but acknowledges its symbolic value.'}

summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the media coverage of the Jeffrey Epstein case, its political implications, and the relevance of a recently surfaced letter allegedly written by Donald Trump to Epstein.

Given the current Republican Congress, you know, pretty in throat to the president, if he wants changes and the economy goes down and it's blamed on Chairman Powell, he'll get them.

lines.text: But then, Professor Siegel, doesn't it matter who then fills that void and whether the market trusts that they will be acting independently if Fed Chair Powell were to step down? Doesn't it matter more for the sanctity of this kind of independence notion for the Fed? Who takes his place?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, his independence already has been, you know, greatly diminished. He's only going to be chairman in most 10 more months, and it's going to be less than that, especially if Trump, you know, announces a shadow chairman. Furthermore, you know, there's two good candidates, Kevin Warsh, Kevin Hassett. Kevin Hassett, I know extremely well. Kevin Warsh, I listened closely to his—it was on Squawk Box yesterday morning. I was very impressed with his analysis.  I think he would be an excellent chairman. By the way, both of them have actually far more monetary training than does Jay Powell. So I think we're not handing this to a hack. Yeah, would interest rates go down a little bit faster?  Probably, yes. Is that a disaster? Really, no. I mean, there's many, many economists. I'm one of them. But we heard from Waller. There are several others. And probably the most famous one, the Taylor rule, which John Taylor, who almost became Fed chairman, has been the most followed and talked about rule for setting rates, says the Fed funds rate should be in the 3% range. Now, I know Trump has said 2, 1, and all that. And that's not going to happen.  But there is a case. Right now, I think, it's so politically compromised, he's going to go into the meeting, and anyone who supports lower rates is going to be considered a Trump lackey.  Listen, I want Trump to own this economy. No scapegoat. If he gets to pick someone and the economy goes south, he really doesn't have anyone to blame. Oh, he'll probably try to blame Powell for something in the past. You know, he's still blaming Biden for things in the past. But that won't have the credibility that if Powell does make a mistake here, it would be very bad for the Fed.  And if things go well, let's assume the economy booms. Do you think Powell is going to get any credit? Do you think the Fed is going to get any credit? No. It's going to be the, you know, the big, beautiful bill. It's going to be, you know, Trump's tax cuts, Trump's tariff, Trump's deregulation. No one is going to remember Chairman Powell. No one's going to say he's the one that caused it. So there's no upside.  This is a difficult situation. I mean, I'm not giving good choices here. I'm just saying, perhaps the least bad choice, you still serve at the pleasure—you know, every four years, the president chooses you. He chooses every member of the board. He chooses the chair. He chooses the vice chair. So, how much independence really is there?  You want to maintain the ability not to be able to just say, OK, you're the reason this economy didn't well. Nothing to do with my policy. And I'm afraid that if the economy goes south, there will be more and more people that will believe that explanation.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Questions the potential consequences of Fed Chair Powell's actions and the impact on the Fed's independence. They probe into the implications of Powell's resignation and the likelihood of maintaining market trust in the new appointee.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Argues that Fed Chair Powell should step down to protect the long-term independence of the Federal Reserve. They believe that Powell will be blamed for any economic downturn by former President Trump, who could then seek to increase his control over the Fed. SPEAKER_01 suggests that two potential successors, Kevin Warsh and Kevin Hassett, are more monetarily trained than Powell and that interest rates might only decrease slightly faster under their leadership. They propose that this move could prevent Trump from using Powell as a scapegoat and make him accountable for the economy's performance, potentially enhancing the Fed's independence in the future.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the independence of the Federal Reserve and the potential implications of Fed Chair Powell's actions. SPEAKER_01 suggests that Powell's stepping down might paradoxically enhance the Fed's long-term independence. They argue that if the economy falters, Powell will be a scapegoat for former President Trump, who could then demand more powers over the Fed from Congress. SPEAKER_01 proposes that this scenario could be avoided if Powell steps down now, allowing Trump to 'own' the economy and its outcomes, and potentially appointing a more independent successor.
